chunk:
Generative AI in Real -World Workplaces  
The Second Microsoft Report on AI and Productivity Research  
 
 
Editors:  
Sonia Jaffe, Neha Parikh Shah, Jenna Butler, Alex Farach, Alexia Cambon, Brent Hecht , Michael Schwarz, and Jaime Teevan   
Contributing Researchers :  
Reid Andersen, Margarita Bermejo -Cano, James Bono, Georg Buscher, Chacha Chen, Steven Clarke, Scott Counts , Eleanor Dillon,  
Ben Edelman, Ulrike Gruber -Gremlich, Cory Hilke, Ben Hanrahan, Sandra Ho, Brian Houck, Mansi Khemka,  Viktor Kewenig, 
Madeline Kleiner, Eric Knudsen, Sathish Manivannan, Max Meijer, Jennifer Neville, Nam Ngo, Donald Ngwe, Ried Peckham, Sida 
Peng, Nora Presson,  Nagu Rangan , Reetchatha Rangareddy , Sean Rintel, Roberto Rodriguez, Katie Rotella, Tara Safavi,  Advait 
Sarkar, Ava Elizabeth Scott, Abigail Sellen, Chirag Shah, Auste Simkute, Tyler Smith, Shwetha Srinath, Siddharth Suri, An-Jen 
Tai, Lev Tankelevitch, Mengting Wan, Leijie Wang , Ryen White, and Longqi Yang   
(with additional support from the entire AI and Productivity team at Microsoft)  
ABSTRACT  
This report presents the most recent findings of Microsoft’s 
research initiative on AI and Productivity , which seeks to measure 
and understand  the productivity gains associated with LLM -
powered productivity tools like Microsoft Copilot. The report 
synthesizes research results from over a dozen  recent studies 
conducted by researchers at Microsoft, with a focus on studies of 
generative AI in actual workplace  environments . One of these is, to 
our knowledge , the largest , randomized controlled trial of the 
introduction of generative AI into organizations.  Overall, the 
research suggests that generative AI is already aiding workers in 
becoming more productive in their day -to-day jobs in significant 
ways. However, t he influence of generative AI is subject to 
variation by role, function, and organization and is contingent upon 
adoption and utilization. The report explores these variations and 
underscores the potential for AI to h ave even greater impact as 
individual

entities.name: AI AND PRODUCTIVITY TEAM AT MICROSOFT
entities.description: The AI and Productivity team at Microsoft provided additional support for the Second Microsoft Report on AI and Productivity Research

entities.name: GENERATIVE AI
entities.description: Generative AI refers to AI technologies that can generate content and assist in various tasks, contributing to productivity gains in workplaces

entities.name: MICROSOFT COPILOT
entities.description: Microsoft Copilot is an LLM-powered productivity tool developed by Microsoft to aid in workplace productivity

entities.name: RANDOMIZED CONTROLLED TRIAL
entities.description: A large, randomized controlled trial conducted by Microsoft to study the introduction of generative AI into organizations

entities.name: LLM-POWERED PRODUCTIVITY TOOLS
entities.description: LLM-powered productivity tools are technologies that leverage large language models to enhance productivity in various tasks

entities.name: PRODUCTIVITY GAINS
entities.description: Productivity gains refer to the improvements in efficiency and output achieved through the use of certain tools or methods

entities.name: WORKPLACE ENVIRONMENTS
entities.description: Workplace environments refer to the settings in which employees perform their job tasks, which can be influenced by various factors including technology

entities.name: DAY-TO-DAY JOBS
entities.description: Day-to-day jobs refer to the regular tasks and responsibilities that employees handle on a daily basis

entities.name: ROLE
entities.description: Role refers to the specific function or position an employee holds within an organization

entities.name: FUNCTION
entities.description: Function refers to the specific activities or duties associated with a particular role within an organization

entities.name: ORGANIZATION
entities.description: Organization refers to a group of people structured and managed to meet a need or pursue collective goals

entities.name: ADOPTION
entities.description: Adoption refers to the acceptance and integration of new tools or methods within an organization

entities.name: UTILIZATION
entities.description: Utilization refers to the extent to which a tool or method is used effectively within an organization

id="GENERATIVE AI">      <data key="d0">TECHNOLOGY</data>      <data key="d1">Generative AI refers to AI technologies that can generate content and assist in various tasks, contributing to productivity gains in workplaces</data>      <data key="d2">644d7a7f0fa5b1428c1fafe65258b2c0</data>      <data key="d3">TECHNOLOGY</data>    </node>    <node id="MICROSOFT COPILOT">      <data key="d0">TECHNOLOGY</data>      <data key="d1">Microsoft Copilot is an LLM-powered productivity tool developed by Microsoft to aid in workplace productivity</data>      <data key="d2">644d7a7f0fa5b1428c1fafe65258b2c0</data>      <data key="d3">TECHNOLOGY</data>    </node>    <node id="RANDOMIZED CONTROLLED TRIAL">      <data key="d0">STUDY</data>      <data key="d1">A large, randomized controlled trial conducted by Microsoft to study the introduction of generative AI into organizations</data>      <data key="d2">644d7a7f0fa5b1428c1fafe65258b2c0</data>      <data key="d3">STUDY</data>    </node>    <node id="LLM-POWERED PRODUCTIVITY TOOLS">      <data key="d0">TECHNOLOGY</data>      <data key="d1">LLM-powered productivity tools are technologies that leverage large language models to enhance productivity in various tasks</data>      <data key="d2">644d7a7f0fa5b1428c1fafe65258b2c0</data>    </node>    <node id="PRODUCTIVITY GAINS">      <data key="d0">CONCEPT</data>      <data key="d1">Productivity gains refer to the improvements in efficiency and output achieved through the use of certain tools or methods</data>      <data key="d2">644d7a7f0fa5b1428c1fafe65258b2c0</data>    </node>    <node id="WORKPLACE ENVIRONMENTS">      <data key="d0">CONCEPT</data>      <data key="d1">Workplace environments refer to the settings in which employees perform their job tasks, which can be influenced by various factors including technology</data>      <data key="d2">644d7a7f0fa5b1428c1fafe65258b2c0</data>    </node>    <node id="DAY-TO-DAY JOBS">      <data key="d0">CONCEPT</data>      <data key="d1">Day-to-day jobs refer to the regular tasks and responsibilities that employees handle on a daily basis</data>      <data key="d2">644d7a7f0fa5b1428c1fafe65258b2c0</data>    </node>    <node id="ROLE">      <data key="d0">CONCEPT</data>      <data key="d1">Role refers to the specific function or position an employee holds within an organization</data>      <data key="d2">644d7a7f0fa5b1428c1fafe65258b2c0</data>    </node>    <node id="FUNCTION">      <data key="d0">CONCEPT</data>      <data key="d1">Function refers to the specific activities or duties associated with a particular role within an organization</data>      <data key="d2">644d7a7f0fa5b1428c1fafe65258b2c0</data>    </node>    <node id="ORGANIZATION">      <data key="d0">CONCEPT</data>      <data key="d1">Organization refers to a group of people structured and managed to meet a need or pursue collective goals</data>      <data key="d2">644d7a7f0fa5b1428c1fafe65258b2c0</data>    </node>    <node id="ADOPTION">      <data key="d0">CONCEPT</data>      <data key="d1">Adoption refers to the acceptance and integration of new tools or methods within an organization</data>      <data key="d2">644d7a7f0fa5b1428c1fafe65258b2c0</data>    </node>    <node id="UTILIZATION">      <data key="d0">CONCEPT</data>      <data key="d1">Utilization refers to the extent to which a tool or method is used effectively within an organization</data>      <data key="d2">644d7a7f0fa5b1428c1fafe65258b2c0</data>    </node>    <edge chunk:
their day -to-day jobs in significant 
ways. However, t he influence of generative AI is subject to 
variation by role, function, and organization and is contingent upon 
adoption and utilization. The report explores these variations and 
underscores the potential for AI to h ave even greater impact as 
individuals and organizations recalibrate their work practices to 
harness AI in the places where it provides the most value . 
 
Please cite this report as:  
Jaffe, S., Shah, N.P., Butler, J., Farach, A., Cambon, A., Hecht, B., 
Schwarz, M. and Teevan, J. eds. 2024. Generative AI in Real -World 
Workplaces: The Second Microsoft Report on AI and Productivity 
Research. Microsoft.  
1 INTRODUCTION  
There is tremendous  interest in how AI can increase people’s 
productivity at work. To help meet this interest, in December 2023, 
Microsoft released a first AI and Productivity Report  (Cambon et 
al. 2023) synthesizing the results of many Microsoft studies on AI 
and productivity. These studies contributed to a large and growing 
literature from around the world and a wide variety of disciplines. 
Although there are exceptions, this literature largely points to a 
broad conclusion: Generative AI tools have the potential to 
introduce  a substantial step -function increase in productivity for tasks performed by information workers (e.g. , Noy and Zhang 
2023; Dell’Acqua et al. 2023; Brynjolfsson et al. 2023; Peng et al. 
2023). 
 
However, much of this existing literature on AI and productivity is 
limited in that it consists primarily of lab-based studies. In these 
studies, participants use d generative AI tools to complete 
researcher -designed tasks in a controlled, simulated work 
environment , largely with a focus on tasks that the researchers 
hypothesized would be amenable to generative AI. Now that a 
much larger population of workers has access to generative AI 
tools, we can begin to understand the impact of these tools outside 
of a lab setting, as people perform their everyday jobs. This has 
begun to allow researchers at Microsoft and elsewhere to study how 
the first wave of generative AI tools impacts information work in 
real-world contexts.  
 
Accordingly, this second Microsoft AI and Productivity Report

entities.name: GENERATIVE AI
entities.description: Generative AI refers to artificial intelligence technologies that can create new content, such as text, images, or music, and have the potential to significantly impact productivity in various roles and functions

entities.name: PRODUCTIVITY
entities.description: Productivity refers to the efficiency and effectiveness with which tasks and activities are completed, often measured in terms of output per unit of input

entities.name: ROLE
entities.description: A role refers to a specific position or function within an organization, which can be influenced by the adoption and utilization of generative AI

entities.name: FUNCTION
entities.description: Function refers to the specific activities or tasks performed within an organization, which can be impacted by generative AI

entities.name: ORGANIZATION
entities.description: An organization is a group of people structured and managed to meet a need or pursue collective goals, and its productivity can be influenced by generative AI

entities.name: ADOPTION
entities.description: Adoption refers to the acceptance and integration of new technologies, such as generative AI, within an organization or by individuals

entities.name: UTILIZATION
entities.description: Utilization refers to the extent to which generative AI tools are used effectively within an organization or by individuals

entities.name: MICROSOFT
entities.description: Microsoft is a technology company that conducts research on AI and productivity and has released reports on the subject

entities.name: AI AND PRODUCTIVITY REPORT
entities.description: The AI and Productivity Report is a document released by Microsoft that synthesizes research findings on the impact of AI on productivity

entities.name: JAFFE, S.
entities.description: S. Jaffe is an editor of the second Microsoft AI and Productivity Report

entities.name: SHAH, N.P.
entities.description: N.P. Shah is an editor of the second Microsoft AI and Productivity Report

entities.name: BUTLER, J.
entities.description: J. Butler is an editor of the second Microsoft AI and Productivity Report

entities.name: FARACH, A.
entities.description: A. Farach is an editor of the second Microsoft AI and Productivity Report

entities.name: CAMBON, A.
entities.description: A. Cambon is an editor of the second Microsoft AI and Productivity Report and an author of a study included in the first report

entities.name: HECHT, B.
entities.description: B. Hecht is an editor of the second Microsoft AI and Productivity Report

entities.name: SCHWARZ, M.
entities.description: M. Schwarz is an editor of the second Microsoft AI and Productivity Report

entities.name: TEEVAN, J.
entities.description: J. Teevan is an editor of the second Microsoft AI and Productivity Report

entities.name: INFORMATION WORKERS
entities.description: Information workers are individuals whose primary job involves handling or using information, and they are significantly impacted by generative AI tools

entities.name: NOY AND ZHANG 2023
entities.description: A study referenced in the AI and Productivity Report, authored by Noy and Zhang in 2023, discussing the impact of generative AI on productivity

entities.name: DELL’ACQUA ET AL. 2023
entities.description: A study referenced in the AI and Productivity Report, authored by Dell’Acqua and others in 2023, discussing the impact of generative AI on productivity

entities.name: BRYNJOLFSSON ET AL. 2023
entities.description: A study referenced in the AI and Productivity Report, authored by Brynjolfsson and others in 2023, discussing the impact of generative AI on productivity

entities.name: PENG ET AL. 2023
entities.description: A study referenced in the AI and Productivity Report, authored by Peng and others in 2023, discussing the impact of generative AI on productivity

entities.name: SECOND MICROSOFT REPORT
entities.description: The Second Microsoft Report on AI and Productivity Research is a document edited by Jaffe, S., Shah, N.P., Butler, J., Farach, A., Cambon, A., Hecht, B., Schwarz, M., and Teevan, J. in 2024, exploring the impact of generative AI in real-world workplaces

entities.name: LAB-BASED STUDIES
entities.description: Lab-based studies are controlled experiments where participants use generative AI tools to complete researcher-designed tasks in a simulated work environment

entities.name: REAL-WORLD CONTEXTS
entities.description: Real-world contexts refer to actual work environments where generative AI tools are used by workers in their everyday jobs

impact of these tools outside 
of a lab setting, as people perform their everyday jobs. This has 
begun to allow researchers at Microsoft and elsewhere to study how 
the first wave of generative AI tools impacts information work in 
real-world contexts.  
 
Accordingly, this second Microsoft AI and Productivity Report 
focuses on Microsoft studies that explore how people apply Copilot  
and other generative AI tools  to their regular work. The report also 
describes learnings from a small set of additional lab experiments 
that suggest new ways that we might see the impact of Copilot in -
the-wild in future studies. Overall, the results – including those 
from what we believe is the single largest randomized controlled 
trial on the introduction of generative AI in real  workplaces – point 
to several high -level observations:  
 
• Generative AI is already helping people be measurably more  
productive in their day -to-day jobs. 
• As expected, the productivity story in real -world workflows 
is more complex than observed in lab studies.   
• Productivity gains associated with generative  AI, including 
time and accuracy, vary by role, function and organization . 
• Variance in adoption and utilization influen ces AI’s impact. 
• Early studies suggest generative  AI may affect the cognitive 
effort required for task completion.   Jaffe et al. 2024  
 
2 
 The goal of th is report is to synthesize learnings from studies from 
around the company versus to completely describe each individual 
study. Many of the studies are or will be the subject of dedicated 
reports or research papers , and we have provided links to those 
documents where they are already available. Most of the studies 
have not yet been through peer review and as such they have not 
had the chance thus far to incorporate external reviewer feedback. 
Further, before continuing , it is important to acknowledge that all 
work here was funded by Microsoft, which has a commercial 
interest in improving and demonstrating the degree to which 
Copilot increases worker productivity.  
2 RELATED WORK  
Researchers outside of Microsoft also have been moving to study 
generative AI ’s impact on productivity in real-world contexts. This 
section highlights a few of the most notable studies in this space . 
These studies  consistently show that the gains predicted by  lab 
studies do indeed translate into significant impact when AI is used 
for real work . Further, they begin to reveal  some nuances in how

entities.name: MICROSOFT
entities.description: Microsoft is a technology company conducting studies on the impact of generative AI tools on productivity

entities.name: SECOND MICROSOFT AI AND PRODUCTIVITY REPORT
entities.description: The Second Microsoft AI and Productivity Report focuses on how people apply Copilot and other generative AI tools to their regular work

entities.name: COPILOT
entities.description: Copilot is a generative AI tool used by people in their regular work to increase productivity

entities.name: GENERATIVE AI TOOLS
entities.description: Generative AI tools are technologies that help people be more productive in their day-to-day jobs

entities.name: INFORMATION WORK
entities.description: Information work involves tasks that require significant cognitive effort and expertise, often performed by knowledge workers

entities.name: LAB EXPERIMENTS
entities.description: Lab experiments are controlled studies conducted to understand the impact of generative AI tools in a controlled environment

entities.name: REAL-WORLD CONTEXTS
entities.description: Real-world contexts refer to the actual work environments where people use generative AI tools in their everyday jobs

entities.name: RANDOMIZED CONTROLLED TRIAL
entities.description: A randomized controlled trial is a study design used to measure the impact of generative AI tools in real workplaces

entities.name: PRODUCTIVITY
entities.description: Productivity refers to the efficiency and effectiveness with which tasks are completed, often measured in terms of time and accuracy

entities.name: COGNITIVE EFFORT
entities.description: Cognitive effort refers to the mental energy required to complete tasks, which may be affected by the use of generative AI tools

entities.name: JAFFE ET AL. 2024
entities.description: A study referenced in the report, authored by Jaffe and others in 2024, suggesting new ways to see the impact of Copilot in future studies

entities.name: PEER REVIEW
entities.description: Peer review is a process where studies are evaluated by external reviewers to incorporate feedback and ensure quality

entities.name: COMMERCIAL INTEREST
entities.description: Commercial interest refers to the financial and business motivations behind conducting studies, such as Microsoft's interest in demonstrating Copilot's effectiveness

entities.name: EXTERNAL RESEARCHERS
entities.description: Researchers outside of Microsoft who are also studying the impact of generative AI on productivity in real-world contexts

entities.name: RESEARCHERS
entities.description: Researchers are individuals or groups conducting studies on the impact of generative AI tools on productivity

entities.name: STUDIES
entities.description: Studies are systematic investigations conducted to understand the impact of generative AI tools on productivity

entities.name: LEARNINGS
entities.description: Learnings refer to the insights and knowledge gained from studies on the impact of generative AI tools

entities.name: WORKER PRODUCTIVITY
entities.description: Worker productivity refers to the efficiency and effectiveness of workers in completing tasks, which can be influenced by generative AI tools

entities.name: TASK COMPLETION
entities.description: Task completion involves finishing assigned tasks, which may be affected by the use of generative AI tools

entities.name: ADOPTION
entities.description: Adoption refers to the extent to which generative AI tools are accepted and used by workers in their daily tasks

entities.name: UTILIZATION
entities.description: Utilization refers to how generative AI tools are used by workers to enhance productivity

entities.name: VARIANCE
entities.description: Variance refers to the differences in the impact of generative AI tools on productivity across different roles, functions, and organizations

entities.name: ROLES
entities.description: Roles refer to the specific job functions or positions held by workers, which can influence the impact of generative AI tools on productivity

entities.name: FUNCTIONS
entities.description: Functions refer to the specific activities or tasks performed by workers, which can influence the impact of generative AI tools on productivity

entities.name: ORGANIZATIONS
entities.description: Organizations are entities where workers perform tasks and use generative AI tools to enhance productivity

entities.name: LAB STUDIES
entities.description: Lab studies are controlled experiments conducted to understand the impact of generative AI tools in a laboratory setting

entities.name: REAL WORK
entities.description: Real work refers to the actual tasks performed by workers in their everyday jobs, where generative AI tools are applied

entities.name: DOCUMENTS
entities.description: Documents are written reports or papers that describe the findings of studies on the impact of generative AI tools

entities.name: RESEARCH PAPERS
entities.description: Research papers are academic articles that present the results of studies on the impact of generative AI tools

entities.name: EXTERNAL REVIEWER FEEDBACK
entities.description: External reviewer feedback is the evaluation and comments provided by reviewers outside the organization to improve the quality of studies

chunk:
on productivity in real-world contexts. This 
section highlights a few of the most notable studies in this space . 
These studies  consistently show that the gains predicted by  lab 
studies do indeed translate into significant impact when AI is used 
for real work . Further, they begin to reveal  some nuances in how 
AI is used , highlighting the importance of contextual factors such 
as skill or task selection on AI’s impact and providing early 
evidence that the presence of AI may impact people’s behavior  and 
the larger ecosystem . 
 
Brynjolfsson et al . (2023) introduced  one of the earliest studies of 
generative AI in real-world work environments. They stud ied an 
AI-based conversational assistant for customer service agents in a 
call center , and found that agents with the assistant resolved 14% 
more issues per hour than those without the assistant. Consistent 
with what has been observed in some lab studies (e.g., Noy and 
Zhang 2023), t he largest impact was on novice and low -skilled 
workers, with very little effect on experience d or highly -skilled 
workers. 
 
However, observing larger benefits for less-skilled workers is 
certainly not universal . Otis et al. ( 2024) examined the effects of a 
generative AI -powered entrepreneurship support tool  on Kenyan 
entrepreneurs’ business performance via an index measure based 
on profit and revenue . They found that entrepreneurs with above -
median performance prior to the start of the experiment saw gains 
of 0.19 standard deviations in performance when using the AI tool, 
while entrepreneurs with below -median performance  saw a 
decrease of 0.09 standard deviations. Though the two groups used 
the tool similar amounts, they tended to ask different types of 
questions. This finding  emphasizes  the importance of contextual 
factors in the productivity gains seen by using generative AI, a key 
observation of this report as well.  
 
In addition , some early real -world studies show that the presence 
of AI may have cascading effects , not just affecting productivity on 
a given task, but also changing which tasks people choose to do.  
For example, Wiles and Horton (202 4) explored how having an 
LLM generat e a first draft of a job posting affected postings and 
hiring on a large online labor market. They f ound that the AI tool 
decre

entities.name: PRODUCTIVITY
entities.description: Productivity refers to the efficiency with which tasks and work are completed, often measured in terms of output per unit of input

entities.name: AI
entities.description: AI, or artificial intelligence, refers to the simulation of human intelligence in machines that are programmed to think and learn

entities.name: BRYNJOLFSSON ET AL. 2023
entities.description: A study conducted by Brynjolfsson and others in 2023, focusing on the use of generative AI in real-world work environments, specifically in a call center

entities.name: NOY AND ZHANG 2023
entities.description: A study referenced in the text, conducted by Noy and Zhang in 2023, observing the impact of AI in lab settings

entities.name: OTIS ET AL. 2024
entities.description: A study conducted by Otis and others in 2024, examining the effects of a generative AI-powered entrepreneurship support tool on Kenyan entrepreneurs' business performance

entities.name: WILES AND HORTON 2024
entities.description: A study conducted by Wiles and Horton in 2024, exploring the impact of an LLM-generated first draft of job postings on a large online labor market

entities.name: GENERATIVE AI
entities.description: Generative AI refers to AI systems that can generate content, such as text, images, or other media, based on input data

entities.name: CONVERSATIONAL ASSISTANT
entities.description: An AI-based tool used in customer service to assist agents in resolving issues more efficiently

entities.name: CUSTOMER SERVICE AGENTS
entities.description: Individuals who assist customers by resolving their issues and providing support, often in a call center environment

entities.name: ENTREPRENEURSHIP SUPPORT TOOL
entities.description: A generative AI-powered tool designed to assist entrepreneurs in improving their business performance

entities.name: KENYAN ENTREPRENEURS
entities.description: Business owners in Kenya who participated in a study examining the impact of a generative AI-powered support tool on their business performance

entities.name: LLM
entities.description: Large Language Model, a type of AI that can generate human-like text based on input data

entities.name: JOB POSTINGS
entities.description: Advertisements or announcements for job openings, often posted on online labor markets

entities.name: ONLINE LABOR MARKET
entities.description: A digital platform where employers can post job openings and job seekers can apply for positions

entities.name: REAL-WORLD CONTEXTS
entities.description: Real-world contexts refer to practical, everyday environments where tasks and activities are performed outside of controlled lab settings

entities.name: LAB STUDIES
entities.description: Lab studies are research experiments conducted in controlled environments to observe specific variables and outcomes

entities.name: SKILL
entities.description: Skill refers to the ability to perform tasks well, often gained through training or experience

entities.name: TASK SELECTION
entities.description: Task selection involves choosing specific tasks to perform, which can impact productivity and outcomes

entities.name: BEHAVIOR
entities.description: Behavior refers to the actions or reactions of individuals in response to external or internal stimuli

entities.name: ECOSYSTEM
entities.description: Ecosystem in this context refers to the interconnected environment in which people and AI interact, including social and organizational factors

entities.name: NOVICE WORKERS
entities.description: Novice workers are individuals who are new to a job or task and have limited experience

entities.name: LOW-SKILLED WORKERS
entities.description: Low-skilled workers are individuals who perform tasks that require minimal training or expertise

entities.name: EXPERIENCED WORKERS
entities.description: Experienced workers are individuals who have significant experience and expertise in their job or task

entities.name: HIGHLY-SKILLED WORKERS
entities.description: Highly-skilled workers are individuals who possess advanced skills and expertise in their field

entities.name: PERFORMANCE
entities.description: Performance refers to the effectiveness and efficiency with which tasks are completed, often measured in terms of output or results

entities.name: PROFIT
entities.description: Profit is the financial gain obtained when the revenue from business activities exceeds the expenses

entities.name: REVENUE
entities.description: Revenue is the total income generated from business activities before any expenses are deducted

entities.name: STANDARD DEVIATIONS
entities.description: Standard deviations are statistical measures that quantify the amount of variation or dispersion in a set of values

entities.name: INDEX MEASURE
entities.description: An index measure is a composite statistic that aggregates multiple indicators to provide a summary measure of performance or other attributes

entities.name: CASCADE EFFECTS
entities.description: Cascade effects refer to the chain reactions or secondary impacts that occur as a result of an initial change or event

chunk:
but also changing which tasks people choose to do.  
For example, Wiles and Horton (202 4) explored how having an 
LLM generat e a first draft of a job posting affected postings and 
hiring on a large online labor market. They f ound that the AI tool 
decreased time spent writing posts and increase d the number of posts completed but  had no effect on the number of hires. The 
researchers suggest this may be because the additional jobs that get 
posted were less important than their other jobs and using AI to 
draft may have caused employers to  exert less effort in writing the 
job posts, leaving them with fewer well -matched applicants.  In 
another example, Yeverechyahu et al . (2024) studied generative AI 
effects on coding activity, both quantity and type . Specifically, the 
authors compared  open-source repositories for packages in Python 
(which was supported by GitHub Copilot) to R (which was not). 
They found a significant jump in contributions due to GitHub 
Copilot. Of note, the increase was larger for contributions  
categorized as “maintenance solutions” than for those categorized 
as “new code development ,” which require more extrapolative 
thinking.  
 
In addition to impacting human behavior, t he real-world presence 
of generative AI may also influence the future behavior of AI 
systems themselves . Rio-Chanona et al. (2023) provide evidence 
that the availability of generative AI programming tools 
substantially reduced participation in online programming forums 
that produce important training data for these tools . This suggests 
that in some contexts  a “paradox of reuse” dynamics (Taraborelli 
2015; McMahon  et al. 2017) might be emerging in the generative 
AI ecosystem. These dynamics could significantly harm 
productivity ga ins if not properly addressed  (Vincent 2022).  
3 STUDIES AND RESULTS  
We now provide an overview of  studies recently conducted  by 
researchers at Microsoft , focusing in particular on those that speak 
to real-world implications of generative AI.  
Studies of workers using AI on the job  
Early Access Program Telemetry Study (Eleanor Dillon, Sonia 
Jaffe, Sida Peng , and Alexia Cambon ) 
Working with over 60 organizations and including over 6000 
individual employees across a wide range of industries and 
occupations, researchers  conducted a large-scale randomized 
controlled

chunk:
job  
Early Access Program Telemetry Study (Eleanor Dillon, Sonia 
Jaffe, Sida Peng , and Alexia Cambon ) 
Working with over 60 organizations and including over 6000 
individual employees across a wide range of industries and 
occupations, researchers  conducted a large-scale randomized 
controlled field experiment of Copilot for M icrosoft 365 – relying 
on participants using the tool in their day -to-day work as opposed 
to on researcher -defined tasks in a lab context. We believe this 
research is the largest controlled study of productivity impacts in 
real-world generative AI deployments to date.   
Researchers worked with  organizations in the Copilot for Microsoft 
365 (M365) Early Access Program to create a randomized control 
trial. Copilot for Microsoft 365  combines  generative AI tools in 
applications such as Word, Excel, PowerPoint, Outlook, Teams, 
and others. Each organization set aside at least 50 licenses to be 
randomly assigned among 100 or more M icrosoft 365 users 
nominated  by the organization . Researchers partnered closely with 
IT administrators and business decision -makers in each of the over 
60 participating organizations to explain the need for 
randomization and obtain buy -in. To ensure privacy, r esearchers Generative AI in Real -World Workplaces  Microsoft Technical Report  
 
3 
 looked only at aggregate effects and did not analyze or report 
individual -level data . 
 
Using metadata from M icrosoft 365 in these organizations, 
researchers compared how email, meeting, and document behavior 
differed based on being assigned a Copilot license. Researchers 
found that on average,  those with Copilot for Microsoft 365  read 
11% fewer individual emails and spent 4% less time interacting 
with them, compared to people without Copilot. Some 
organizations saw larger effects with relative decreases of up to 20 
or 25% in both emails read and time spent interacting with email. 
The top grap h in Figure 1 shows the effects across organizations. 
The researchers hypothesize that  the summarize emails feature in 
Copilot for Outlook and the Copilot chat function may have 
allowed workers to retrieve information without reading or 
rereading individual  emails. 
 
The effects of Copilot on the number of meetings attended (via 
Microsoft  Teams) were more complex, with some organizations 
seeing significant increases , others seeing significant decreases , 
and others seeing no significant effect .

allowed workers to retrieve information without reading or 
rereading individual  emails. 
 
The effects of Copilot on the number of meetings attended (via 
Microsoft  Teams) were more complex, with some organizations 
seeing significant increases , others seeing significant decreases , 
and others seeing no significant effect . Of the 47 organizations that 
have been in the study the longest, 10 saw a statistically significant 
decrease in attended meetings, with an average decrease of .39 
meetings per day on a pre -Copilot average of 3 meetings. On the 
other hand, 14 customers saw a statistically significa nt increase in 
meetings with an average increase of .36 meetings per day on a pre -
Copilot average of 2 meetings. The difference in baseline average 
suggests that increases  in meetings  attended were more likely at 
organizations with low levels of baseline Teams usage. The 
remaining customers did not see a statistically significant change in 
the number of Teams meetings. The middle graph in Figure 1 plots 
the effect for each customer.  
 
Teams Copilot provides meeting summaries and uses the transcript 
to answer questions users may ask of it during or after a meeting, 
but only works for meetings that are executed in Teams.  Thus, 
having access gives people an additional reason to have meetings 
in Teams (instead of only in -person or via another app) , so 
increases could reflect increases in the use of Teams that are not 
indicative of increases in overall meetings. More generally, if 
Copilot makes meetings both more effective and more efficient , 
that can generate conflicting effects : more efficient meetings 
require less time and fewer follow -up meetings, but if meetings 
become more effective collaboration tools, they may be used for a 
wider range of projects or tasks.  
 
With respect to documents, people with Copilot also created and 
edited more documents than those without Copilot. Overall people 
edited 10% more documents, with heavy users of Word, Excel, and 
PowerPoint seeing an increase of 13% (on a higher baseline). So me 
organizations saw increases in the 25 -30% range. One hypothesis 
is this is an early sign of the writing and creation assistance that 
Copilot provides making it easier to produce  and revise  output. 
Alternatively, people may be using some of the time they save with 
Copilot to do additional document creation and editing.

entities.name: COPILOT
entities.description: Copilot is a tool that assists workers by providing functionalities such as meeting summaries and answering questions based on meeting transcripts

entities.name: MICROSOFT TEAMS
entities.description: Microsoft Teams is a collaboration platform used for meetings and communication within organizations

entities.name: ORGANIZATIONS
entities.description: Organizations are entities that participated in the study to observe the effects of Copilot on meetings and document creation

entities.name: MEETINGS
entities.description: Meetings are scheduled gatherings, often conducted via Microsoft Teams, to discuss and collaborate on various topics

entities.name: DOCUMENTS
entities.description: Documents are files created and edited by users, including Word, Excel, and PowerPoint files

entities.name: WORD
entities.description: Word is a word processing software used for creating and editing text documents

entities.name: EXCEL
entities.description: Excel is a spreadsheet software used for data organization and analysis

entities.name: POWERPOINT
entities.description: PowerPoint is a presentation software used for creating and editing slideshows

entities.name: USERS
entities.description: Users are individuals who utilize Copilot and Microsoft Teams for their work tasks

entities.name: MEETING SUMMARIES
entities.description: Meeting summaries are concise overviews of meetings provided by Copilot

entities.name: TRANSCRIPTS
entities.description: Transcripts are written records of spoken content during meetings, used by Copilot to answer questions

entities.name: STUDY
entities.description: The study is an ongoing research project observing the effects of Copilot on meetings and document creation within organizations

entities.name: FIGURE 1
entities.description: Figure 1 is a graph that plots the effect of Copilot on the number of meetings attended by each customer

entities.name: INFORMATION RETRIEVAL
entities.description: Information retrieval is the process of obtaining information from a large repository, such as emails, without reading or rereading individual messages

entities.name: MEETING ATTENDANCE
entities.description: Meeting attendance refers to the act of participating in scheduled meetings, which can be affected by the use of Copilot

entities.name: CUSTOMERS
entities.description: Customers are organizations or individuals who use Microsoft Teams and Copilot and are part of the study

entities.name: BASELINE TEAMS USAGE
entities.description: Baseline Teams usage refers to the initial level of Microsoft Teams usage within an organization before the introduction of Copilot

entities.name: EFFECTIVENESS
entities.description: Effectiveness refers to how well meetings achieve their intended outcomes, which can be influenced by Copilot

entities.name: EFFICIENCY
entities.description: Efficiency refers to the amount of time and resources required to conduct meetings, which can be improved by Copilot

entities.name: WRITING ASSISTANCE
entities.description: Writing assistance is a feature of Copilot that helps users create and revise documents more easily

entities.name: CREATION ASSISTANCE
entities.description: Creation assistance is a feature of Copilot that aids users in producing new documents

entities.name: REVISION ASSISTANCE
entities.description: Revision assistance is a feature of Copilot that helps users edit and improve existing documents

chunk:
range. One hypothesis 
is this is an early sign of the writing and creation assistance that 
Copilot provides making it easier to produce  and revise  output. 
Alternatively, people may be using some of the time they save with 
Copilot to do additional document creation and editing.   
 This study is still under way , and researchers are planning to 
explore additional outcomes (e.g., amount of time spent per 
document ) as well as  spillovers and team effects  (e.g., the impact 
of a worker’s collaborators having Copilot). This study is limited 
by its focus on work processes. That is, though telemetry can 
provide an objective measure of activity, th ere is not a direct 
mapping between the observed outcomes (number of documents, 
emails, etc) and productivity , performance or business outcomes . 
Moreover , to preserve privacy, the study observes  activity, not the 
content created, so it cannot study quality or how well output aligns 
with people’s goals or intents.  
Work Trend Index Survey  
More study details available in AI at Work Is Here. Now Comes the 
Hard Part  (Microsoft and LinkedIn 2024)  
To understand the impact of generative AI on workplace 
productivity and satisfaction, Microsoft conducted the 2024 Work 
Trend Index Survey. This 20 -minute, anonymous survey was 
administered by Edelman Data & Intelligence to 31,000 full -time 
employed or sel f-employed knowledge workers across 31 countries  
Figure 1. Effects across organizations of access to Copilot for 
M365 on emails read, scheduled meetings attended, and files 
edited in Word, Excel, and PowerPoint .  
 Jaffe et al. 2024  
 
4 
 between February 15, 2024, and March 28, 2024. The survey aimed 
to capture user sentiments and experiences with generative AI 
broadly as opposed to focusing on any specific generative AI tool 
such as Copilot.  
 
One key finding from the survey is the widespread use of 
unsanctioned AI tools among employees. The survey revealed that, 
of respondents who used AI, 78% used  at least some AI tools not 
provided by their organization.  This highlights a significant 
phenomenon where many employees turn to external AI resources 
to meet their needs.  
 
Additionally, a  significant focus of the Work Trend Index data 
analyses is “AI Power Users ,”

entities.name: COPILOT
entities.description: Copilot is a tool that provides writing and creation assistance, making it easier to produce and revise output

entities.name: STUDY
entities.description: The study is ongoing and aims to explore additional outcomes such as the amount of time spent per document and the impact of a worker’s collaborators having Copilot

entities.name: TELEMETRY
entities.description: Telemetry provides an objective measure of activity but does not directly map observed outcomes to productivity, performance, or business outcomes

entities.name: WORK TREND INDEX SURVEY
entities.description: The Work Trend Index Survey is a 20-minute, anonymous survey conducted by Microsoft to understand the impact of generative AI on workplace productivity and satisfaction

entities.name: MICROSOFT
entities.description: Microsoft is a technology company that conducted the 2024 Work Trend Index Survey

entities.name: LINKEDIN
entities.description: LinkedIn collaborated with Microsoft on the report "AI at Work Is Here. Now Comes the Hard Part"

entities.name: EDELMAN DATA & INTELLIGENCE
entities.description: Edelman Data & Intelligence administered the Work Trend Index Survey to 31,000 full-time employed or self-employed knowledge workers across 31 countries

entities.name: JAFFE ET AL. 2024
entities.description: A study referenced in the document, authored by Jaffe and others in 2024

entities.name: KNOWLEDGE WORKERS
entities.description: Knowledge workers are full-time employed or self-employed individuals who participated in the Work Trend Index Survey

entities.name: AI POWER USERS
entities.description: AI Power Users are individuals who make significant use of AI tools, as highlighted in the Work Trend Index data analyses

entities.name: UNSANCTIONED AI TOOLS
entities.description: Unsanctioned AI tools are AI resources not provided by the organization but used by employees to meet their needs

entities.name: WRITING AND CREATION ASSISTANCE
entities.description: Writing and creation assistance refers to the support provided by tools like Copilot to make it easier to produce and revise output

entities.name: DOCUMENT CREATION AND EDITING
entities.description: Document creation and editing involve producing and modifying documents, potentially facilitated by tools like Copilot

entities.name: TIME SPENT PER DOCUMENT
entities.description: Time spent per document is a metric being explored in the study to understand the impact of Copilot on productivity

entities.name: SPILLOVERS AND TEAM EFFECTS
entities.description: Spillovers and team effects refer to the impact of one worker’s use of Copilot on their collaborators

entities.name: PRIVACY
entities.description: Privacy is a consideration in the study, which observes activity but not the content created to preserve user privacy

entities.name: PRODUCTIVITY
entities.description: Productivity refers to the efficiency and effectiveness of work processes, which the study aims to measure

entities.name: PERFORMANCE
entities.description: Performance refers to the quality and outcomes of work, which the study aims to measure

entities.name: BUSINESS OUTCOMES
entities.description: Business outcomes refer to the results and impacts of work on the organization, which the study aims to measure

entities.name: QUALITY
entities.description: Quality refers to how well the output aligns with people’s goals or intents, which the study cannot measure due to privacy constraints

entities.name: USER SENTIMENTS AND EXPERIENCES
entities.description: User sentiments and experiences refer to the feelings and perceptions of users regarding generative AI, captured by the Work Trend Index Survey

entities.name: EMPLOYEES
entities.description: Employees are individuals who participated in the Work Trend Index Survey and use AI tools

entities.name: EXTERNAL AI RESOURCES
entities.description: External AI resources are AI tools not provided by the organization but used by employees to meet their needs

chunk:
78% used  at least some AI tools not 
provided by their organization.  This highlights a significant 
phenomenon where many employees turn to external AI resources 
to meet their needs.  
 
Additionally, a  significant focus of the Work Trend Index data 
analyses is “AI Power Users ,” which researchers defined as 
individuals reporting being familiar with generative AI, using it at 
work at least several times a week, and saving more than 30 minutes 
a day by using it . Overall, 29% of respondents who used AI fell into 
this bucket. Power users had noticeably lower use of unsanctioned 
AI (66% vs . the non-power user average of 83%, p<.05) . 
 
Researchers sought to understand which factors from the survey 
were most predictive of the power user classification; they focused 
on several survey questions categorized into three areas:  
• Actions: Actions related to generative AI at work.  
• Methods: Methods of AI usage.  
• Outcomes: Feelings or outcomes related to respondent AI 
usage. 
 
The survey responses were analyzed to build a model identifying 
the key predictors of AI power user classification. The data 
preparation and modeling process included addressing class imbalance using the Synthetic Minority Over -sampling Technique 
(SMOTE) and evaluating model performance through cross -
validation. Researchers implemented two predictive models: 
Random Forest and Logistic Regression. The Random Forest 
model outperformed Log istic Regression with an accuracy of 0.744 
and a ROC -AUC score of 0.737,  compared to Logistic Regression's 
accuracy of 0.657 and ROC -AUC score of 0.695. Consequently, 
the Random Forest model was trained on the entire dataset to 
pinpoint the key predictors of AI power usage.  
 
As seen in Figure 2, regular experimentation with AI emerged as 
the most significant predictor of AI power usage classification. This 
factor was a stronger predictor of power user classification than 
other AI specific methods, actions, or outcomes. The imp ortance 
score, measured by a Random Forest statistical model, should be 
interpreted relatively, as it shows how much each feature helps in 
predicting AI power usage compared to others. Higher scores 
indicate greater importance. In this analysis, scores ran ge from 361 
to 882, highlighting the significant factors influencing AI power 
user classification within this dataset and model.  
 
As with all surveys of this type

indicate greater importance. In this analysis, scores ran ge from 361 
to 882, highlighting the significant factors influencing AI power 
user classification within this dataset and model.  
 
As with all surveys of this type, it is important to view all the above 
results through the lens of the limitations of the methodology. 
While the analysis reveals significant associations, causation 
cannot be conclusively established due to the observational nature 
of the data. Similarly, s elf-selection bias, response bias, and 
unmeasured confounding variables such as workplace culture and 
managerial support could influence the outcomes.  
Copilot Usage in the Workplace Survey (Alexia Cambon , Alex 
Farach, Margarita Bermejo -Cano, and Eric Knudsen ) 
More study findings available in AI Data Drop: The 11 by 11 
Tipping Point  
While the Work Trend Index survey described above focused on 
generative AI in general , researchers also conducted  a broad survey 
focused specifically on Copilot for Microsoft 365, asking enterprise 
Copilot users  about their  perceived benefits, time savings, and 
overall job satisfaction.  This 20-minute, anonymous survey , which 
is ongoing, is being distributed to people with Copilot licenses at 
participating customer organizations from October 1, 2023, to 
November 1, 2024. Analysis here is based on 885 responses 
collected up to February 1, 2024 , from people  who had used 
Copilot for more than three weeks  at the time of survey response . 
  
The survey results suggest that people who use d Copilot for an 
extended period receive significant benefits from doing so. 
Researchers analyzed three distinct categories of usage durations: 
3-6 weeks, 7 -10 weeks, and more than 10 weeks. The analysis 
employed a 5 -point Likert scale, where 1 represents " Strongly 
Disagree" and 5 represents "Strongly Agree."  
 
Respondents who had been using Copilot for more than 10 weeks 
reported greater benefits compared to those with shorter usage 
durations. For example, for the question "Using Copilot in Teams 
allows me to attend fewer meetings," those using Copilot for 3 -6

10 weeks 
reported greater benefits compared to those with shorter usage 
durations. For example, for the question "Using Copilot in Teams 
allows me to attend fewer meetings," those using Copilot for 3 -6  
Figure 2. Variable importance in predicting AI power usage  
Generative AI in Real -World Workplaces  Microsoft Technical Report  
 
5 
 weeks had an average response of 2.66 ( variance 0.81) and those 
with more than 10 weeks of usage had an average of 3.06 ( variance 
1.34). For the question “Using Copilot helps me to enjoy my work 
more” the average for the 3 -6 week group was 3.4 and for the over 
10-weeks group it was 3.6.  All results reported in this analysis are 
statistically significant, as confirmed by ANOVA tests (p < 0.05).  
 
It is essential to acknowledge the limitations of this self-reported 
data. While  researchers  found significant associations, establishing 
causation is challenging. People who are more inclined to use 
productivity tools like Copilot may also be those who naturally 
experience higher job satisfaction, creating potential self -selection 
bias. Additionally, unmeasured factors such as managerial support 
or workplace culture could  influence both Copilot usage and job 
satisfaction.  This study also relied  on self-reported data that 
introduces the possibility of response bias.  
Study on Generative Search Engines and Task Complexity  
(Siddharth Suri, Scott Counts, Leijie Wang, Chacha Chen, 
Mengting Wan, Tara Safavi, Jennifer Neville, Chirag Shah, Ryen 
W. White, Reid Andersen, Georg Buscher, Sathish Manivannan, 
Nagu Rangan, and Longqi Yang ) 
More study details available in The Use of Generative Search 
Engines for Knowledge Work and Complex Tasks  (Suri et al. 2024) 
Search is a  common task in real-world workflows . To understand 
how the use of AI-augmented search differs from traditional search, 
researchers analyzed 80 ,000 randomly selected, de -identified 
conversations from the consumer version of Copilot in Bing and 
traditional Bing searches . They used GPT -4 to classify each 
conversation and search by topic domain. They found that  chats 
with Bing Copilot tend to focus on

chunk:
, 
researchers analyzed 80 ,000 randomly selected, de -identified 
conversations from the consumer version of Copilot in Bing and 
traditional Bing searches . They used GPT -4 to classify each 
conversation and search by topic domain. They found that  chats 
with Bing Copilot tend to focus on topics related to knowledge 
work, such as “Translation and language learning ,” “Creative 
writing and editing ,” and “Programming and scripting.”  Overall, 
72.9% of the Copilot conversations are in knowledge work domains 
compared to 37% of Bing Search sessions . The researchers  also 
used GPT-4 to directly classify whether the task associated with 
each Copilot conversation and or search session was knowledge 
work (instead of classifying based on the category) and see a similar 
pattern.  
 
Researchers then used GPT-4 to classify the main task associated 
with each conversation or search sessions according to Anderson 
and Krathwohl’s Taxonomy (Anderson and Krathwohl 2001) , 
which defines six categories from lowest complexity (for a human) 
to highest: Remember, Understand, Apply, Analyze, Evaluate, and 
Create. Over three -quarters of traditional search sessions, but less 
than half of Copilot conversations were for “Remember” tasks. 
Grouping “Remember” and “Understand ” as low-complexity  tasks 
and the rest as high -complexity, the authors found 13.4 % of 
traditional search sessions and 37% of Copilot sessions were high -
complexity. That is, AI -augmented search tended to be in higher 
complexity domains than traditional search.  
 
Researchers interpret the shift in domain and complexity of tasks 
between traditional search and Copilot as generative AI  helping people with tasks that used to be done with much more human 
effort; LLMs shift the frontier of which tasks machines can help 
with – and how helpful they are.  Researchers caveat that these 
results are based on early usage of Bing Copilot and patterns may 
change as the tools develop and users gain experience working with 
them. Nonetheless, the study suggests that LLMs will affect 
substantial changes in how people use search -based tools and 
accomplish knowledge work tasks more broadly.  
 
The study could not identify when people were using consumer 
Copilot for their jobs, but the high number of knowledge work tasks 
is consistent with

entities.name: RESEARCHERS
entities.description: Researchers analyzed conversations and searches to understand the usage patterns of Bing Copilot and traditional Bing searches

entities.name: COPILOT
entities.description: Copilot is a feature in Bing that assists users with various tasks, particularly in knowledge work domains

entities.name: BING
entities.description: Bing is a search engine developed by Microsoft

entities.name: GPT-4
entities.description: GPT-4 is an advanced language model used to classify conversations and searches by topic domain and task complexity

entities.name: KNOWLEDGE WORK
entities.description: Knowledge work involves tasks that require significant cognitive effort and expertise, such as translation, language learning, creative writing, and programming

entities.name: TRADITIONAL SEARCH
entities.description: Traditional search refers to the standard search sessions conducted on Bing without the assistance of Copilot

entities.name: ANDERSON AND KRATHWOHL'S TAXONOMY
entities.description: A taxonomy that defines six categories of cognitive complexity: Remember, Understand, Apply, Analyze, Evaluate, and Create

entities.name: REMEMBER TASKS
entities.description: Tasks that involve recalling information, considered the lowest complexity in Anderson and Krathwohl's Taxonomy

entities.name: UNDERSTAND TASKS
entities.description: Tasks that involve comprehending information, considered low complexity in Anderson and Krathwohl's Taxonomy

entities.name: HIGH-COMPLEXITY TASKS
entities.description: Tasks that involve applying, analyzing, evaluating, or creating information, considered higher complexity in Anderson and Krathwohl's Taxonomy

entities.name: LOW-COMPLEXITY TASKS
entities.description: Tasks that involve remembering and understanding information, considered lower complexity in Anderson and Krathwohl's Taxonomy

entities.name: LLMS
entities.description: Large Language Models, such as GPT-4, that assist in performing complex tasks and shifting the frontier of machine-assisted tasks

entities.name: CONVERSATIONS
entities.description: Conversations refer to the interactions users have with Bing Copilot

entities.name: SEARCH SESSIONS
entities.description: Search sessions refer to the traditional searches conducted on Bing

entities.name: TRANSLATION AND LANGUAGE LEARNING
entities.description: Translation and language learning are types of knowledge work tasks focused on understanding and using different languages

entities.name: CREATIVE WRITING AND EDITING
entities.description: Creative writing and editing are types of knowledge work tasks focused on producing and refining written content

entities.name: PROGRAMMING AND SCRIPTING
entities.description: Programming and scripting are types of knowledge work tasks focused on writing and debugging code

entities.name: ANDERSON AND KRATHWOHL 2001
entities.description: A study that defines Anderson and Krathwohl's Taxonomy, which categorizes cognitive tasks by complexity

entities.name: REMEMBER
entities.description: Remember tasks involve recalling information and are considered the lowest complexity in Anderson and Krathwohl's Taxonomy

entities.name: UNDERSTAND
entities.description: Understand tasks involve comprehending information and are considered low complexity in Anderson and Krathwohl's Taxonomy

entities.name: APPLY
entities.description: Apply tasks involve using information in new situations and are considered higher complexity in Anderson and Krathwohl's Taxonomy

entities.name: ANALYZE
entities.description: Analyze tasks involve breaking information into parts to explore understandings and relationships, considered higher complexity in Anderson and Krathwohl's Taxonomy

entities.name: EVALUATE
entities.description: Evaluate tasks involve making judgments based on criteria and standards, considered higher complexity in Anderson and Krathwohl's Taxonomy

entities.name: CREATE
entities.description: Create tasks involve putting elements together to form a coherent or functional whole, considered the highest complexity in Anderson and Krathwohl's Taxonomy

chunk:
, the study suggests that LLMs will affect 
substantial changes in how people use search -based tools and 
accomplish knowledge work tasks more broadly.  
 
The study could not identify when people were using consumer 
Copilot for their jobs, but the high number of knowledge work tasks 
is consistent with the finding in the Work Trend Index report that 
many employees were using generative AI tools not provided by 
their companies in their work.   
Specific Roles and Functions  
In addition to the studies above, which span across a range of 
knowledge workers,  some studies also look at how results differ 
across roles and study generative AI tools developed for use  cases 
of a specific role or profession. Following a comparison across 
roles, we take a closer look at the software development functio n. 
Because of the earlier availability of GitHub Copilot, there is a lot 
of research in that area which may lend insight  to effects to be 
expected in  other types of information work.  
Comparing across Roles in Copilot Usage in the Workplace 
Survey (Alexia Cambon , Alex Farach , Margarita Bermejo -Cano, 
and Eric Knudsen ) 
The Copilot Usage in the Workplace Survey  described above 
helped researchers understand broad patterns, but also allowed us  
to look at data by job type to see  the impact on specific roles and 
functions, focusing on  two dimensions: adoption and perceived 
benefits. All reported differences are statistically  significant at 
p<.05, using ANOVA tests, with the Benjamini -Hochberg False 
Discovery Rate (FDR) control procedure applied.  
 
When asked about usage (1=never, 5=daily), respondents across 
nearly all functions reported using Copilot in Teams  at least 
weekly, with some functions like sales and product development 
reporting daily usage (average response scores of 4.66 and 4.55, 
respectively). Others functions like legal and supply chain reported 
somewhat lower usage (4.03 and 3.88, respectively). Reported 
usage of Copilot in Outlook  was generally slightly lower, but with 
similar patterns across roles .  
 
Respondents with communication -focused responsibilities 
involving repetitive and/or content creation tasks supported by 
current AI capabilities also reported the most benefits from Copilot , 
including productivity , fulfillment , work quality improvements , 
and efficiency . In contrast, those

chunk:
generally slightly lower, but with 
similar patterns across roles .  
 
Respondents with communication -focused responsibilities 
involving repetitive and/or content creation tasks supported by 
current AI capabilities also reported the most benefits from Copilot , 
including productivity , fulfillment , work quality improvements , 
and efficiency . In contrast, those in roles involving more variable 
and/or complex tasks not yet fully optimized by current AI 
capabilities, including legal and R&D, reported fewer benefits.  
Some distinctions also may be attributed to highly regulated 
industries or sensitive use cases . It is likely, however, that  AI tools 
will be improved  over time to support these scenarios.   Jaffe et al. 2024  
 
6 
 Specifically , when asked about increased productivity with Copilot 
(“When using Copilot I am more productive ” with 1="Strongly 
Disagree" and 5 ="Strongly Agree" ), the reported effect was highest 
among professionals in customer service and sales ( mean of 4.2 and 
3.97, respectively), and lowest among legal professionals ( mean of 
3.0). For fulfillment (“When using Copilot I feel more fulfilled in 
my work”) customer service and sales functions reported the 
highest mean agreement (3.53 and 3.41, respectively) with R&D 
and legal functions experiencing the lowest mean agreement (2.74 
and 2.90, respectively).  Additionally, c ustomer service and product 
development professionals rated the improvement in work quali ty 
(“Using Copilot helps improve the quality of my work”) highest, 
with mean scores of 4.2 0 and 3.93, respectively. In contrast, legal 
professionals again reported lower improvement scores, averaging 
3.19.  
 
In terms of efficiency and information management, customer 
service, creative, and sales professionals reported significant ease 
in catching up on missed meetings and retrieving necessary 
information, with mean response scores of 4.27, 4.4 0, and 4.45, 
respectively. Again, legal and operations functions had the lowest 
mean scores for meeting efficiency at 3.28 and 3.75, respectively.  
 
As noted above, this study  shares the limits of all surveys in relying 
on self-reports. Moreover, there may be differences across 
professions in how people perceive the subjective metrics like 
quality and fulfillment  that the survey asked about .   
Towards Effective

As noted above, this study  shares the limits of all surveys in relying 
on self-reports. Moreover, there may be differences across 
professions in how people perceive the subjective metrics like 
quality and fulfillment  that the survey asked about .   
Towards Effective AI Support for Developers: A Survey of 
Desires and Concerns (Mansi Khemka  and Brian Houck ) 
More details available in Towards Effective AI Support for 
Developers: A Survey of Desires and Concerns  (Khemka and 
Houck, 2024 ).  
Microsoft researchers surveyed 800 Microsoft developers and 
explored the opportunities and concerns that they have with using 
AI in their work.  Responses indicated that developers most want to 
see AI help with  automating routine tasks, like generating unit tests 
and writing documentation, which they find monotonous but 
essential. Specifically, 44% of respondents highlighted generating 
tests as a top area where AI could alleviate the burden and improve 
developer experience . Additionally, 42% noted AI's potential in 
analyzing code for defects and optimizations, seeing it as a virtual 
pair-programming partner. Writing documentation was another 
area of interest, with 37%  seeing AI's potential in automating this 
crucial but often neglected task.  
 
However, developers also voiced significant concerns. The top 
worry (29%) was that AI might not be as helpful as expected . 
Another major concern (21%) was that AI might introduce defects 
or vulnerabilities, emphasizing the need for thorough validation 
and human oversight. Job security was a worry for 10% of 
respondents, reflecting fears of AI encroaching on their roles.  
 
These learnings suggest developers view AI as helpful to 
improving aspects of their workflows, even as they remain uncertain of AI’s promise and concerned about threats to their job 
security. To mitigate the negative effects of this uncertainty on 
productivity and innovation, and to maintain developers ’ trust and 
satisfaction, organizations may identify ways to integrate AI into 
developers' workflows effectively. These may include 
acknowledging and addressing concerns and offering training 
programs.  
Problem-Solving Styles and Confidence Generating Prompts 
for GitHub Copilot (Steven Clarke and Ben Hanrahan ) 
This study explored how developers ’ problem-solving styles 
influence their confidence when generating prompts for GitHub 
Copilot. The authors hypothesized that variations

entities.name: MICROSOFT

entities.name: DEVELOPERS
entities.description: Developers are professionals who write and maintain software code, and in this context, they are surveyed about their experiences and concerns with AI support in their work

entities.name: AUTOMATING ROUTINE TASKS
entities.description: Automating routine tasks refers to the use of AI to handle repetitive and monotonous tasks such as generating unit tests and writing documentation, which are essential but time-consuming for developers

entities.name: ANALYZING CODE FOR DEFECTS AND OPTIMIZATIONS
entities.description: Analyzing code for defects and optimizations involves using AI to review code for potential errors and areas for improvement, acting as a virtual pair-programming partner for developers

entities.name: WRITING DOCUMENTATION
entities.description: Writing documentation is the process of creating and maintaining written records of software code, which is crucial for understanding and maintaining the software but often neglected by developers

entities.name: JOB SECURITY
entities.description: Job security refers to the concern among developers that AI might encroach on their roles, potentially leading to job loss

entities.name: VALIDATION AND HUMAN OVERSIGHT
entities.description: Validation and human oversight involve ensuring that AI-generated outputs are thoroughly checked and verified by humans to prevent defects or vulnerabilities

entities.name: TRAINING PROGRAMS
entities.description: Training programs are initiatives that organizations can offer to help developers effectively integrate AI into their workflows and address their concerns

entities.name: SURVEY
entities.description: A method of gathering information from individuals, in this case, used to collect data from Microsoft developers about their desires and concerns regarding AI support

entities.name: SELF-REPORTS
entities.description: Self-reports are a type of data where individuals provide information about themselves, often used in surveys

entities.name: QUALITY
entities.description: Quality is a subjective metric used in the survey to assess the developers' perception of their work

entities.name: FULFILLMENT
entities.description: Fulfillment is a subjective metric used in the survey to assess the developers' sense of satisfaction with their work

entities.name: OPPORTUNITIES
entities.description: Opportunities refer to the potential benefits and positive outcomes that developers see in using AI in their work

entities.name: CONCERNS
entities.description: Concerns refer to the potential drawbacks and negative outcomes that developers see in using AI in their work

entities.name: ROUTINE TASKS
entities.description: Routine tasks are repetitive and monotonous activities that developers perform, such as generating unit tests and writing documentation

entities.name: GENERATING UNIT TESTS
entities.description: Generating unit tests is a routine task where developers create tests to verify that individual units of code work as intended

entities.name: ANALYZING CODE
entities.description: Analyzing code involves reviewing software code to identify defects and areas for optimization

entities.name: DEFECTS
entities.description: Defects are errors or bugs in software code that need to be identified and fixed

entities.name: OPTIMIZATIONS
entities.description: Optimizations refer to improvements made to software code to enhance its performance and efficiency

entities.name: VIRTUAL PAIR-PROGRAMMING PARTNER
entities.description: A virtual pair-programming partner is an AI tool that assists developers by providing suggestions and feedback, similar to a human pair-programming partner

entities.name: DEVELOPER EXPERIENCE
entities.description: Developer experience refers to the overall satisfaction and efficiency of developers in their work, which can be improved by using AI tools

entities.name: HELPFULNESS
entities.description: Helpfulness refers to the degree to which AI tools meet developers' expectations and assist them in their work

entities.name: DEFECTS OR VULNERABILITIES
entities.description: Defects or vulnerabilities are potential issues introduced by AI tools that could compromise the quality and security of software code

entities.description: Productivity refers to the efficiency and output of developers in their work, which can be affected by the integration of AI tools

entities.name: INNOVATION
entities.description: Innovation refers to the introduction of new ideas and methods in software development, which can be influenced by the use of AI tools

entities.name: TRUST
entities.description: Trust refers to the confidence developers have in AI tools and their ability to assist without causing harm or reducing job security

entities.description: Satisfaction refers to the contentment developers feel with their work and the tools they use, including AI tools

programs.  
Problem-Solving Styles and Confidence Generating Prompts 
for GitHub Copilot (Steven Clarke and Ben Hanrahan ) 
This study explored how developers ’ problem-solving styles 
influence their confidence when generating prompts for GitHub 
Copilot. The authors hypothesized that variations in developers’ 
problem-solving approaches and workstyles would significantly 
influence their interactions with Copilot, thereby affecting their 
confidence and productivity outcomes.  
 
To explore this hypothesis, the authors employed the GenderMag 
survey (Burnett et al. 2016; Anderson et al . 2024), a tool 
specifically designed to investigate the impact of differences in 
people’s problem -solving styles when working with technology. 
This survey was used along with additional questions about 
confidence in Copilot prompting overall and for different 
scenarios.  A third-party recruiting firm recruited participants who 
worked in programing roles, had done so for at least six months, 
and used Git Hub Copilot at work. The survey was sent to 250 
people, yielding 212 usable responses.  To analyze the data, 
researchers ran a regression model to measure the extent to which 
years of experience, time using Copilot, and each GenderMag trait, 
(Computer self -efficacy, risk -aversion, info -processing style, 
motivation for technology use, and learning style ), explained 
respondents’ confidence in each scenario.   
 
The study found that the duration for which developers have been 
using GitHub Copilot was the most significant factor explaining 
their prompting confidence. They also found that confidence in 
prompting is inversely related to the number of years of 
professional software development experience. While this may 
seem counterintuitive, it could be because they are more familiar 
with or attached to existing workflows or because more 
experience d developer s are better able  to spot errors and 
inaccuracies in Copilot  responses. If they attribute those errors to 
their prompts, it could make them less confident that they can create 
successful prompts.  The analysis also showed that developers with 
a comprehensive approach to information processing and 
developers who are motivated to use technology for its own sake 
are also more confident in generating prompts. These findings echo 
those above suggesting b enefits of usage increase over time.  
GitHub Copilot and Engineering System Satisfaction  (An-Jen 
Tai, Shwetha Srinath , and Re

entities.name: GITHUB COPILOT
entities.description: GitHub Copilot is an AI-powered code completion tool that assists developers by generating code snippets and suggestions

entities.name: PROBLEM-SOLVING STYLES
entities.description: Problem-solving styles refer to the various approaches and methods developers use to tackle coding challenges and generate prompts for GitHub Copilot

entities.name: CONFIDENCE
entities.description: Confidence in this context refers to developers' self-assurance in their ability to generate effective prompts for GitHub Copilot

entities.name: STEVEN CLARKE
entities.description: Steven Clarke is one of the authors of the study on problem-solving styles and confidence in generating prompts for GitHub Copilot

entities.name: BEN HANRAHAN
entities.description: Ben Hanrahan is one of the authors of the study on problem-solving styles and confidence in generating prompts for GitHub Copilot

entities.name: GENDERMAG SURVEY
entities.description: The GenderMag survey is a tool designed to investigate the impact of differences in people's problem-solving styles when working with technology

entities.name: BURNETT ET AL. 2016
entities.description: A study referenced in the context of the GenderMag survey, authored by Burnett and others in 2016

entities.name: ANDERSON ET AL. 2024
entities.description: A study referenced in the context of the GenderMag survey, authored by Anderson and others in 2024

entities.name: THIRD-PARTY RECRUITING FIRM
entities.description: A recruiting firm that was responsible for recruiting participants for the study on GitHub Copilot

entities.name: PARTICIPANTS
entities.description: Participants in the study were individuals working in programming roles, who had been using GitHub Copilot for at least six months

entities.name: REGRESSION MODEL
entities.description: A statistical method used by researchers to analyze the data and measure the impact of various factors on developers' confidence in generating prompts

entities.name: COMPUTER SELF-EFFICACY
entities.description: Computer self-efficacy refers to a person's belief in their ability to effectively use computers and technology

entities.name: RISK-AVERSION
entities.description: Risk-aversion is a trait that describes a person's tendency to avoid risks in their decision-making processes

entities.name: INFO-PROCESSING STYLE
entities.description: Info-processing style refers to the way individuals process and analyze information when working with technology

entities.name: MOTIVATION FOR TECHNOLOGY USE
entities.description: Motivation for technology use describes the reasons why individuals are driven to use technology, whether for practical purposes or personal interest

entities.name: LEARNING STYLE
entities.description: Learning style refers to the preferred method or approach an individual uses to learn new information or skills

entities.name: AN-JEN TAI
entities.description: An-Jen Tai is one of the authors of the study on GitHub Copilot and engineering system satisfaction

entities.name: SHWETHA SRINATH
entities.description: Shwetha Srinath is one of the authors of the study on GitHub Copilot and engineering system satisfaction

entities.name: ENGINEERING SYSTEM SATISFACTION
entities.description: Engineering system satisfaction refers to the level of contentment developers have with the engineering systems they use, including tools like GitHub Copilot

entities.name: PRODUCTIVITY OUTCOMES
entities.description: Productivity outcomes refer to the results or impacts on productivity that arise from using tools like GitHub Copilot

entities.name: PROMPTING CONFIDENCE
entities.description: Prompting confidence refers to the self-assurance developers have in their ability to generate effective prompts for GitHub Copilot

entities.name: YEARS OF EXPERIENCE
entities.description: Years of experience refers to the amount of time developers have spent in professional software development roles

entities.name: TIME USING COPILOT
entities.description: Time using Copilot refers to the duration for which developers have been using GitHub Copilot

entities.name: DEVELOPERS
entities.description: Developers are individuals who write and maintain code, and in this context, they are users of GitHub Copilot

entities.name: ERRORS AND INACCURACIES
entities.description: Errors and inaccuracies refer to the mistakes or incorrect suggestions made by GitHub Copilot

entities.name: EXISTING WORKFLOWS
entities.description: Existing workflows refer to the established processes and methods that experienced developers are accustomed to using
