key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">The GenderMag survey was used to investigate the impact of problem-solving styles</data>      <data key="d5">af4b53dd1ef3cde41ca4f98eb20862eb</data>    </edge>    <edge source="CONFIDENCE" target="GENDERMAG SURVEY">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">The GenderMag survey included questions about confidence in generating prompts for GitHub Copilot</data>      <data key="d5">af4b53dd1ef3cde41ca4f98eb20862eb</data>    </edge>    <edge source="CONFIDENCE" target="REGRESSION MODEL">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">A regression model was used to analyze factors affecting developers' confidence in generating prompts</data>      <data key="d5">af4b53dd1ef3cde41ca4f98eb20862eb</data>    </edge>    <edge source="CONFIDENCE" target="COMPUTER SELF-EFFICACY">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">Computer self-efficacy is one of the traits measured to explain confidence in generating prompts</data>      <data key="d5">af4b53dd1ef3cde41ca4f98eb20862eb</data>    </edge>    <edge source="CONFIDENCE" target="RISK-AVERSION">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">Risk-aversion is one of the traits measured to explain confidence in generating prompts</data>      <data key="d5">af4b53dd1ef3cde41ca4f98eb20862eb</data>    </edge>    <edge source="CONFIDENCE" target="INFO-PROCESSING STYLE">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">Info-processing style is one of the traits measured to explain confidence in generating prompts</data>      <data key="d5">af4b53dd1ef3cde41ca4f98eb20862eb</data>    </edge>    <edge source="CONFIDENCE" target="MOTIVATION FOR TECHNOLOGY USE">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">Motivation for technology use is one of the traits measured to explain confidence in generating prompts</data>      <data key="d5">af4b53dd1ef3cde41ca4f98eb20862eb</data>    </edge>    <edge source="CONFIDENCE" target="LEARNING STYLE">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">Learning style is one of the traits measured to explain confidence in generating prompts</data>      <data key="d5">af4b53dd1ef3cde41ca4f98eb20862eb</data>    </edge>    <edge source="THIRD-PARTY RECRUITING FIRM" target="PARTICIPANTS">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">The third-party recruiting firm recruited participants for the study</data>      <data key="d5">af4b53dd1ef3cde41ca4f98eb20862eb</data>    </edge>    <edge source="PROMPTING CONFIDENCE" target="YEARS OF EXPERIENCE">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">Years of experience inversely affects developers' prompting confidence</data>      <data key="d5">af4b53dd1ef3cde41ca4f98eb20862eb</data>    </edge>    <edge source="PROMPTING CONFIDENCE" target="TIME USING COPILOT">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">Time using Copilot is a significant factor in developers' prompting confidence</data>      <data key="d5">af4b53dd1ef3cde41ca4f98eb20862eb</data>    </edge>    <edge source="PROMPTING CONFIDENCE" target="ERRORS AND INACCURACIES">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">Errors and inaccuracies in Copilot responses can affect developers' prompting confidence</data>      <data key="d5">af4b53dd1ef3cde41ca4f98eb20862eb</data>    </edge>    <edge source="PROMPTING CONFIDENCE" target="EXISTING WORKFLOWS">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">Attachment to existing workflows can reduce prompting confidence</data>      <data key="d5">af4b53dd1ef3cde41ca4f98eb20862eb</data>    </edge>    <edge source="YEARS OF EXPERIENCE" target="EXISTING WORKFLOWS">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">Experienced developers may be more attached to existing workflows</data>      <data key="d5">af4b53dd1ef3cde41ca4f98eb20862eb</data>    </edge>  </graph></graphml>

developers who are motivated to use technology for its own sake 
are also more confident in generating prompts. These findings echo 
those above suggesting b enefits of usage increase over time.  
GitHub Copilot and Engineering System Satisfaction  (An-Jen 
Tai, Shwetha Srinath , and Reetchatha Rangareddy ) 
This study considered  how engineering system satisfaction (as 
measured by a net satisfaction score or NSAT) changed for 
Microsoft employees who adopted GitHub Copilot compared to 
those who did not. Researchers  examined  anonymized data  on Generative AI in Real -World Workplaces  Microsoft Technical Report  
 
7 
 >30,000 software engineers , some of whom  had installed and used 
GitHub Copilot between the two waves of Microsoft’s  bi-annual 
Employee Signals Survey , combined  with their survey responses 
on satisfaction with the engineering systems .  
 
The 95% confidence interval for the difference -in-differences 
estimate (the change for the adopters minus the change for the non -
adopters) was ( -2, 4.1), suggesting that Copilot did not have a 
significant effect on employee satisfaction with the engineerin g 
systems. In addition to not finding a statistically significant 
difference, the study suggests that the true difference is less than a 
4pt change, which is not considered substantial since the NSAT 
scale can range from 0 to 200 and the average moves arou nd a few 
points from survey wave to survey wave. This is perhaps 
unsurprising since coding is just a part of what constitutes an 
engineering system for most developers. For example, a prior study 
found developers only spend 21% of their time writing code, with 
the other time spent doing things like reviewing code, attending 
meetings, doing email , and reading technical websites (Meyer et al. 
2017). Satisfaction may have been driven primarily by the other 
tools developers used. The lack of effect could also b e because 
some of the users may have tried  GitHub Copilot , but not used it  
regularly or they lacked training or manager support for use .   
A Selection of New Lab Studies  
While the above research focuses on the use of generative AI  in the 
wild, we are also exploring in a lab setting some of the important 
trends that real-world use highlights . Given AI ’s impact appears to 
vary by role and function, several of these lab

entities.name: DEVELOPERS
entities.description: Developers are individuals who create and maintain software applications and systems

entities.name: TECHNOLOGY
entities.description: Technology refers to the application of scientific knowledge for practical purposes, especially in industry

entities.name: PROMPTS
entities.description: Prompts are inputs or instructions given to AI systems to generate responses or actions

entities.name: GITHUB COPILOT
entities.description: GitHub Copilot is an AI-powered code completion tool that assists developers by suggesting code snippets and functions

entities.name: ENGINEERING SYSTEM SATISFACTION
entities.description: Engineering system satisfaction refers to the level of contentment employees feel towards the engineering tools and systems they use, often measured by a net satisfaction score (NSAT)

entities.name: AN-JEN TAI
entities.description: An-Jen Tai is a researcher involved in the study on engineering system satisfaction and GitHub Copilot

entities.name: SHWETHA SRINATH
entities.description: Shwetha Srinath is a researcher involved in the study on engineering system satisfaction and GitHub Copilot

entities.name: REETCHATHA RANGAREDDY
entities.description: Reetchatha Rangareddy is a researcher involved in the study on engineering system satisfaction and GitHub Copilot

entities.name: MICROSOFT
entities.description: Microsoft is a technology company that conducted a study on the impact of GitHub Copilot on engineering system satisfaction

entities.name: GENERATIVE AI
entities.description: Generative AI refers to artificial intelligence systems that can generate content, such as text, code, or images, based on input prompts

entities.name: MICROSOFT TECHNICAL REPORT
entities.description: The Microsoft Technical Report is a document that includes research findings on the use of generative AI in real-world workplaces

entities.name: EMPLOYEE SIGNALS SURVEY
entities.description: The Employee Signals Survey is a bi-annual survey conducted by Microsoft to gather feedback from employees on various aspects, including satisfaction with engineering systems

entities.name: SOFTWARE ENGINEERS
entities.description: Software engineers are professionals who apply engineering principles to design, develop, maintain, test, and evaluate software and systems

entities.name: NSAT
entities.description: NSAT, or net satisfaction score, is a metric used to measure satisfaction levels, often ranging from 0 to 200

entities.name: MEYER ET AL. 2017
entities.description: A study conducted by Meyer and others in 2017, which found that developers spend only 21% of their time writing code

entities.name: LAB STUDIES
entities.description: Lab studies are controlled experiments conducted to explore specific trends and impacts of AI in a controlled environment

entities.name: CONFIDENCE INTERVAL
entities.description: The confidence interval is a range of values that estimates the true difference in a study, providing a measure of uncertainty

entities.name: DIFFERENCE-IN-DIFFERENCES ESTIMATE
entities.description: The difference-in-differences estimate measures the change for adopters minus the change for non-adopters in a study

entities.name: TRAINING
entities.description: Training refers to the process of teaching or learning skills and knowledge, often necessary for effective use of tools like GitHub Copilot

entities.name: MANAGER SUPPORT
entities.description: Manager support refers to the assistance and encouragement provided by managers to their team members, which can influence the adoption and use of new tools

entities.name: CODING
entities.description: Coding is the process of writing instructions for computers to perform specific tasks, a key part of software development

entities.name: REVIEWING CODE
entities.description: Reviewing code involves examining and providing feedback on code written by others to ensure quality and functionality

entities.name: MEETINGS
entities.description: Meetings are gatherings where people discuss and make decisions on various topics, often part of a developer's work routine

entities.name: EMAIL
entities.description: Email is a method of exchanging digital messages, commonly used for communication in professional settings

entities.name: TECHNICAL WEBSITES
entities.description: Technical websites are online resources that provide information, tutorials, and documentation on various technical topics

entities.name: REAL-WORLD WORKPLACES
entities.description: Real-world workplaces refer to actual work environments where employees perform their job duties

entities.name: ROLE
entities.description: Role refers to the specific function or position an individual holds within an organization

entities.name: FUNCTION
entities.description: Function refers to the specific activities or tasks that an individual or department is responsible for within an organization

chunk:
A Selection of New Lab Studies  
While the above research focuses on the use of generative AI  in the 
wild, we are also exploring in a lab setting some of the important 
trends that real-world use highlights . Given AI ’s impact appears to 
vary by role and function, several of these lab studies explore this, 
diving more deeply into software development and extending th e 
analysis to other important roles like sales and security. Further, 
because Copilot is deployed globally, we ’re also starting to see 
variation across languages, and thus presen t research studies 
looking at AI in multilingual contexts. Finally, the complex trade -
offs people are starting to make to incorporate AI into their work 
practices suggests the cognitive mechanisms underlying its use are 
important to understand, and we share some earl y work in that 
space as well .  
Comparing the Effect of Different Task Types on Effective Use 
of GitHub Copilot  (Steven Clarke and Ben Hanrahan ) 
This study investigated the conditions under which a developer 
might expect to benefit most from GitHub Copilot. The authors 
recruited 23 Java developers with at least one year of professional 
experience and asked them to  perform one of two different tasks. 
Half worked on a task that involved writing new code using familiar 
components and concepts , and the other half worked on a different 
task that involved modifying existing  code using unfamiliar 
components and concepts. For each task, h alf of the participants 
completed the task using Copilot and the other half did not  use it. 
 
All participants were allowed to use any online resources they 
wanted, but those in the Copilot group were first given a 10 -minute 
overview of GitHub Copilot and encouraged to use that. Even with 
these small sample sizes, the researchers found evidence  that the type of task  matters for the impact that Copilot has on the 
developer. With the familiar task Copilot use resulted in 36% time -
savings (p<.05) and 48% fewer issues (p=.12). In contrast , no 
substantial difference was observed between Copilot and non-
Copilot groups  for the less familiar task .  
Understanding the Impact Copilot for Security Has for 
Security Professionals  (Ben Edelman, James Bono, Sida Peng, 
Roberto Rodriguez, and Sandra Ho)  
More details available in Randomized Controlled Trials for 
Microsoft Copilot for Security  (Edelman

Understanding the Impact Copilot for Security Has for 
Security Professionals  (Ben Edelman, James Bono, Sida Peng, 
Roberto Rodriguez, and Sandra Ho)  
More details available in Randomized Controlled Trials for 
Microsoft Copilot for Security  (Edelman et al. 2024)  
Looking at Copilot in the context of another role, security,  
researchers extended the lab experiments reported in the first AI 
and Productivity Report studying Copilot for Security  from security 
novices to security professionals . Participants were  recruited 
through a staffing agency that provides security services to large 
companies , allowing t his new lab study to focus on people who 
currently use security tools as part of their day -to-day jobs. 
 
Of the 147 security professional participants, three -quarters had 5 
or more years of experience as a security analyst. Participants 
logged into an instance of Microsoft’s security service platform, 
Microsoft Defender, that was created for this experiment. There 
they performed various tasks, including writing a summary of the 
incident and answering multiple -choice questions about it. Those 
with Copilot were 7% more accurate on the multiple -choice 
questions (p<.05). Researchers also asked experts for a list o f key 
facts that should have been included in an incident summary. Study 
participants with Copilot included 49% more of those key facts in 
their incident summary reports (p<.05). Because i t is uninformative 
to compare speeds across groups when one group is systematically 
more accurate than another , the researchers looked at quality -
adjusted completion times and f ound that subjects with Copilot 
were 23% faster overall (p<.05 ). 
 
Compared with the previous study  looking at security novices , the 
security professionals in this study experienced significantly 
smaller accuracy gains. This is unsurprising given security 
professionals are more skilled in the tasks and therefore have less 
room for improvement. Nonetheless , the results show that Copilot  
allowed professionals to increase their speed without sacrificing 
accuracy.  
Experiment with Licensing Chatbot for Sellers (Donald Ngwe, 
Ried Peckham, Ulrike Gruber -Gremlich, and Tyler Smith ) 
We next turn to Copilot implications in the sales function. 
Researchers conducted a lab study to understand how a “licensing 
chatbot,” trained on a corpus of materials around Microsoft’s 
licensing policies

chunk:
, 
Ried Peckham, Ulrike Gruber -Gremlich, and Tyler Smith ) 
We next turn to Copilot implications in the sales function. 
Researchers conducted a lab study to understand how a “licensing 
chatbot,” trained on a corpus of materials around Microsoft’s 
licensing policies , facilitated sellers’ ability to answer customer 
questions. The study asked 64 Microsoft sellers to answer both 
multiple-choice and open -ended questions in a Qualtrics survey 
designed to simulate questions that a customer might ask. Sellers 
were randomly assigned to either have or not have access to the 
chatbot. 
  Jaffe et al. 2024  
 
8 
 Having the chatbot improved both speed and accuracy. Sellers with 
the chatbot answered multiple choice questions 3.4 minutes (39%, 
p<.05) faster and accuracy improved by 25 percentage points 
(p<.05). In the open -ended questions, speed, accuracy, 
completene ss, and suitability ratings all improved 34 -56% (p<.05). 
These results suggest a positive potential for AI in sales workflows 
of managing customer sales calls, with potential implications for 
revenue and customer satisfaction outcomes.   
The Effect of Copilot in a Multi -lingual Context (Benjamin 
Edelman and Donald Ngwe)  
Another important source of variation i s language. Researchers 
explored Copilot in multilingual contexts, examining how Copilot 
can facilitate collaboration between colleagues with different 
native languages.  
 
First, researchers  asked 77 native Japanese speakers to review a 
meeting recorded in English . Half the participants had to watch and 
listen to the video. The other half could use Copilot Meeting Recap, 
which gave them an AI meeting summary as well as a chatbot to 
answer questions about the meeting. Then, researchers asked 83 
other native Japanese speakers to review a similar meeting, 
following the same script, but this time held in Japanese  by native 
Japanese speakers. Again, half of participants had access to 
Copilot.  
 
For the meeting in English , participants with Copilot  answered 
16.4% more multiple -choice questions about the meeting correctly, 
and they were more than twice as likely to get a perfect score. 
Moreover , in comparing accuracy between the two scenarios, 
people listening to a meeting in English with Copilot achieved 
97.5% accuracy, slightly more accurate than people listening to

4% more multiple -choice questions about the meeting correctly, 
and they were more than twice as likely to get a perfect score. 
Moreover , in comparing accuracy between the two scenarios, 
people listening to a meeting in English with Copilot achieved 
97.5% accuracy, slightly more accurate than people listening to a 
meeting in their native Japanese using standard tools (94.8%). This 
is a statistically significant difference  (p<.05). The changes are 
somewhat small in percentage point terms because the baseline 
accuracy is so high, but Copilot closed 38.5% of the gap to perfect 
accuracy for those working in their native language (p<0.10) and 
closed 84.6% of the gap for those working in (non -native) English 
(p<.05). 
  
The role of Copilot in communication for non -native speakers has 
also come up in researchers’ interviews with people using Copilot 
in their day -to-day work. At global companies, Copilot may help 
people feel more confident that they are communicating 
effectively. That said, Copilot also raises concerns about potentially 
increasing the dominance of majority languages: in interviews 
conducted by other researchers at Microsoft, some people reported 
changing the language in which meetings were held to one where 
Copilot was more effective. This effect might shrink or go away as 
model performance in other languages improves, and improving 
model performance in non -English languages is a major direction 
of research at Microsoft and around the world (e.g. , Ahuja et al. 
2023). Impact of Generative AI on Metacognition (Lev Tankelevitch, 
Viktor Kewenig, Auste Simkute, Ava Elizabeth Scott, Advait Sarkar, 
Abigail Sellen, and Sean Rintel)  
More details available in The Metacognitive Demands and 
Opportunities of Generative AI  (Tankelevitch , Kewenig  et al. 2024)  
Metacognitive demand —the effort needed for monitoring and 
controlling of one’s thoughts and processes —is a part of cognitive 
load, the total amount of mental effort exerted during tasks. In a 
review paper (published at the recent ACM SIGCHI 2024 
conference) drawing on research in psychology, cognitive science, 
and the first wave of generative AI lab studies, researcher s explored 
how generative

entities.description: Copilot is a tool used to assist in communication, particularly for non-native speakers, by improving accuracy and confidence in understanding and conveying information

entities.name: MEETING
entities.description: A gathering where people discuss various topics, in this context, used to measure the effectiveness of Copilot in improving comprehension and accuracy

entities.name: MICROSOFT
entities.description: Microsoft is a technology company conducting research on Copilot and its impact on communication and productivity

entities.name: RESEARCHERS
entities.description: Researchers are individuals conducting studies and interviews to understand the impact of Copilot on communication and productivity

entities.name: AHUJA ET AL. 2023
entities.description: A study referenced in the context of improving model performance in non-English languages

entities.name: GENERATIVE AI
entities.description: Generative AI refers to artificial intelligence systems capable of generating content and assisting in various tasks, including communication and metacognition

entities.name: METACOGNITION
entities.description: Metacognition involves the monitoring and controlling of one's thoughts and processes, contributing to cognitive load

entities.name: COGNITIVE LOAD
entities.description: Cognitive load is the total amount of mental effort exerted during tasks, including metacognitive demand

entities.name: ACM SIGCHI 2024
entities.description: The ACM SIGCHI 2024 conference is an event where research on human-computer interaction, including studies on generative AI, is presented

chunk:
of cognitive 
load, the total amount of mental effort exerted during tasks. In a 
review paper (published at the recent ACM SIGCHI 2024 
conference) drawing on research in psychology, cognitive science, 
and the first wave of generative AI lab studies, researcher s explored 
how generative AI (not Copilot specifically) changes the 
metacognitive demands of a task. For example, prompt 
engineering, prompt iteration, and output evaluation all require 
metacognitive effort that may not be needed when doing a task 
without assistance. This includes work such as developing explicit 
awareness of task goals, task decomposition, and gaining well -
adjusted confidence in one’s ability to evaluate the output. 
Moreover, the availability of generative AI tools creates a more 
general b urden of deciding how to apply these tools to tasks and 
workflows. To do so “users must have self -awareness of the 
applicability and potential impact of using GenAI for their 
workflow; well -adjusted confidence in the ability to complete a 
task manually ver sus with GenAI; and metacognitive flexibility in 
adapting workflows to GenAI.”  
 
The researchers suggest that the metacognitive demands of 
generative AI can be addressed both by improving users’ 
metacognitive abilities and by reducing the metacognitive demands 
of the tools. Tools could improve metacognitive ability around task 
decompos ition, for example, by responding to a prompt with a list 
of common subtasks and soliciting (optional) input from the user 
for each subtask.  
 
The metacognitive demands of AI tools can be further reduced by 
improving explainability, which can help users calibrate their 
confidence in outputs and prompting techniques, and self -
evaluation or co -auditing. Customizability can either increase or 
decrease metacognitive demands depending on the context; 
customizability may make the tool more fitted to the user’s task and 
ability, reducing the metacognitive work of prompting and 
evaluating, but making customization decisions can also add to 
cognitive load.  As usage spreads and the tools develop, the authors 
argue that research is needed to understand how tools affect 
different users’ metacognitive processes and what design decisions 
can lighten the load.  
Impact of Copilot on Cognitive Load (Madeline Kleiner, Max 
Meijer, Katie Rotella, and Nora Presson

entities.name: COGNITIVE LOAD
entities.description: Cognitive load refers to the total amount of mental effort exerted during tasks

entities.name: ACM SIGCHI 2024
entities.description: The ACM SIGCHI 2024 conference is an event where research in psychology, cognitive science, and generative AI lab studies was presented

entities.name: GENERATIVE AI
entities.description: Generative AI refers to AI systems that can generate content or perform tasks based on prompts and user input

entities.name: PROMPT ENGINEERING
entities.description: Prompt engineering involves creating and refining prompts to guide the output of generative AI tools

entities.name: PROMPT ITERATION
entities.description: Prompt iteration is the process of repeatedly refining prompts to improve the output of generative AI tools

entities.name: OUTPUT EVALUATION
entities.description: Output evaluation involves assessing the quality and relevance of the output generated by AI tools

entities.name: TASK DECOMPOSITION
entities.description: Task decomposition is the process of breaking down a task into smaller, manageable subtasks

entities.name: METACOGNITIVE DEMANDS
entities.description: Metacognitive demands refer to the mental processes involved in planning, monitoring, and evaluating one's own cognitive activities

entities.name: METACOGNITIVE ABILITIES
entities.description: Metacognitive abilities are skills that allow individuals to understand and control their own cognitive processes

entities.name: EXPLAINABILITY
entities.description: Explainability refers to the ability of AI tools to provide understandable explanations for their outputs and processes

entities.name: CUSTOMIZABILITY
entities.description: Customizability is the ability of AI tools to be tailored to fit the specific needs and preferences of the user

entities.name: COPILOT
entities.description: Copilot is a generative AI tool that assists users in completing tasks

entities.name: MADELINE KLEINER
entities.description: Madeline Kleiner is an author of the study on the impact of Copilot on cognitive load

entities.name: MAX MEIJER
entities.description: Max Meijer is an author of the study on the impact of Copilot on cognitive load

entities.name: KATIE ROTELLA
entities.description: Katie Rotella is an author of the study on the impact of Copilot on cognitive load

entities.name: NORA PRESSON
entities.description: Nora Presson is an author of the study on the impact of Copilot on cognitive load

entities.name: PSYCHOLOGY
entities.description: Psychology is the scientific study of the mind and behavior

entities.name: COGNITIVE SCIENCE
entities.description: Cognitive science is the interdisciplinary study of the mind and its processes

entities.name: FIRST WAVE OF GENERATIVE AI LAB STUDIES
entities.description: The first wave of generative AI lab studies refers to initial research efforts focused on understanding the impact and capabilities of generative AI

entities.name: TASK GOALS
entities.description: Task goals are the objectives or desired outcomes that one aims to achieve when performing a task

entities.name: SELF-AWARENESS
entities.description: Self-awareness is the conscious knowledge of one's own character, feelings, motives, and desires

entities.name: METACOGNITIVE FLEXIBILITY
entities.description: Metacognitive flexibility is the ability to adapt one's thinking and strategies to new and changing situations

entities.name: SELF-EVALUATION
entities.description: Self-evaluation is the process of assessing one's own performance and abilities

entities.name: CO-AUDITING
entities.description: Co-auditing involves collaboratively reviewing and assessing the outputs and processes of AI tools

entities.name: USERS
entities.description: Users are individuals who interact with and utilize generative AI tools for various tasks

entities.name: RESEARCHERS
entities.description: Researchers are individuals who conduct studies and investigations to gain new knowledge and insights

argue that research is needed to understand how tools affect 
different users’ metacognitive processes and what design decisions 
can lighten the load.  
Impact of Copilot on Cognitive Load (Madeline Kleiner, Max 
Meijer, Katie Rotella, and Nora Presson)  
One study asked about and tried to measure metacognitive load 
directly. In this study, 40 Microsoft employees who volunteered for 
the study created a sales report in Word based on data in an Excel 
spreadsheet (using a sample report for reference). Half of the 
participants had access to Copilot and half did not. In addition to 
measuring time and accuracy, the study asked participants about Generative AI in Real -World Workplaces  Microsoft Technical Report  
 
9 
 how demanding, hard, stressful, and rushed the task was, and the 
study administered a Stroop test as a measure of participants’ 
cognitive load (Scarpina and Tagini 2017). A Stroop test measures 
participants response times and error rates in a quick classif ication 
task to try to measure the cognitive load they experienced prior to 
the test.  
 
Participants with Copilot reported the task was less mentally 
demanding on average (30 out of 100) than the control group (55 
out of 100). The improvements for perceived stress and difficulty 
were similar, with an even larger difference (28 vs. 67 out of 1 00) 
for how rushed the task felt. All reported differences have t -test 
with p<.05. It seems that , contrary to the concerns raised in the 
previous section, in this case the direct help from Copilot counter -
balanced or outweighed any increase in metacognitiv e load. 
Interestingly, the researchers did not find a difference in the 
average Stroop score. It is possible that while Copilot made the task 
feel easier and more enjoyable, it did not affect participants’ ability 
to do the subsequent task. Alternatively, there ma y have been a 
small effect on the Stroop score that the study did not have the 
statistical power to detect, or the Stroop score did not capture the 
effects observed by the participants in the survey.

We now look across the studies discussed individual ly in this report

effects observed by the participants in the survey.   
4 DISCUSSION  
We now look across the studies discussed individual ly in this report  
to further explore common themes. Collectively , the studies  
suggest generative AI is already having positive effects  on real-
world productivity and begin to highlight the complexity in these 
effects that emerge from taking a more complete view of work  via 
field research.  
As noted above, m ost previous research in this space relied on lab 
studies, which b y and large provide insight into just a small subset 
of the tasks people perform as part of their everyday work.  The 
tasks studied in the lab, for example, have tended to require only 
general knowledge and skill s. In contrast, tasks done in the course 
of work often require highly-specific knowledge and skills. The 
current generation of generative AI models have been trained 
primarily on public data, which means they perform best on the 
types of generic tasks used in these lab studies. Although t he gains 
observed on those tasks in the lab appear to be translating at least 
to some extent to the real-world tasks  that people actually do , it will 
be important to continue studying AI’s impact as models begin to 
become tailored to perform even better within specific 
organizational contexts  or domains. 
 
More generally, t he tasks studied in the lab thus far have tended to 
be those for which researchers hypothesized generative AI would 
perform well . This was, in fact, the focus of most of the studies 
presented in the first AI and Productivity report we published  
(Cambon et al. 2023) . Actual information work , however, often 
includes a huge variety of tasks  and much of the unstructured and 
informal work in people’s jobs is not yet directly supported by the 
first-generation of generative AI tools.  Software developer 
workflows , for example,  involve far more than the hands-on coding supported by GitHub Copilot (Meyer et al. 2017). The ability to 
shed light on generative AI's productivity dynamics in the natural 
complexity of entire workflows is a key advantage of field studies 
of generative AI’s productivity impacts , and a major reason we 
hope to see many more field studies emerging in the literature.  
 
When we look at AI’s use in  the context of real

entities.description: Workflows refer to the sequence of processes through which a piece of work passes from initiation to completion

entities.name: PRODUCTIVITY DYNAMICS
entities.description: Productivity dynamics refer to the changing factors and interactions that affect productivity

generative AI's productivity dynamics in the natural 
complexity of entire workflows is a key advantage of field studies 
of generative AI’s productivity impacts , and a major reason we 
hope to see many more field studies emerging in the literature.  
 
When we look at AI’s use in  the context of real workflows, we see 
that context matters a lot. We discussed some initial findings on 
differences in generative AI usage and effects by an individual’s 
role or function . These findings raise interesting  questions in terms 
of how different roles and functions  will find value from generative 
AI, in terms of efficiencies and also innovation gains . There is an 
opportunity to further study which individuals and business 
processes benefit most from AI, and how organiz ational leaders can 
enable and encourage AI’s productive use. There are also likely 
many additional sources of heterogeneity, including, for instance , 
individuals’ personalities  or the general conditions of the business , 
e.g. as in Otis et al. (2024). 
 
Assuming generative AI follows the path of most general purpose 
technologies (Brynjolfsson and McAfee 2014) , workflows will , 
looking forward,  be substantially redesigned to better integrate  AI. 
Furthermore, generative AI is still under development and the tools 
that make use of it are improving rapidly . This means not only that 
the long-term effects of AI on productivity  will differ from those 
observed in the short -term, but that we are likely to  continue to see 
differences between  local task effects and mo re global productivity 
effects. Research should try to capture and inform change s in 
workflows , task design , and business processes  in addition to 
productivity effects for fixed tasks.   
 
One result seen in the above studies and those in our prior work is 
the common disconnect between the time savings people report 
from Copilot use and the actual time savings measure d. This has 
been observed not only across studies, where survey measures 
about time saved tend to be larger than telemetry -based measures, 
but also within a given study where researchers collect both survey 
and telemetry measures of time saved on a specific  task. There are 
several potential explanations for these effects, deserving of study. 
People may enjoy the experience or be excited by the pursuit of the 
‘answer’ with Copilot, which can reduce or speed perceptions of 
time (N

entities.name: GENERATIVE AI
entities.description: Generative AI refers to artificial intelligence systems that can generate content, such as text, images, or other media, and are used to enhance productivity in various workflows

entities.name: FIELD STUDIES
entities.description: Field studies involve observing and analyzing the use of generative AI in real-world settings to understand its productivity impacts

entities.name: WORKFLOWS
entities.description: Workflows are sequences of tasks or processes through which work passes from initiation to completion, often involving multiple roles and functions

entities.name: ROLES
entities.description: Roles refer to the specific functions or positions individuals hold within an organization, which can influence how they use and benefit from generative AI

entities.name: FUNCTIONS
entities.description: Functions refer to the specific activities or duties performed by individuals within their roles, impacting their use of generative AI

entities.name: EFFICIENCIES
entities.description: Efficiencies refer to the improvements in productivity and performance that can be achieved through the use of generative AI

entities.name: INNOVATION GAINS
entities.description: Innovation gains refer to the new ideas, products, or processes that can result from the use of generative AI

entities.name: ORGANIZATIONAL LEADERS
entities.description: Organizational leaders are individuals in positions of authority who can enable and encourage the productive use of generative AI within a business

entities.name: HETEROGENEITY
entities.description: Heterogeneity refers to the variations and differences among individuals, roles, functions, and business conditions that can affect the use and impact of generative AI

entities.name: PERSONALITIES
entities.description: Personalities refer to the individual characteristics and traits that can influence how people interact with and benefit from generative AI

entities.name: BUSINESS CONDITIONS
entities.description: Business conditions refer to the general environment and circumstances within a business that can impact the use and effectiveness of generative AI

entities.name: OTIS ET AL. 2024
entities.description: A study referenced in the text that discusses the impact of business conditions on the use of generative AI

entities.name: GENERAL PURPOSE TECHNOLOGIES
entities.description: General purpose technologies are technologies that have broad applications and can lead to significant changes in productivity and workflows

entities.name: BRYNJOLFSSON AND MCAFEE 2014
entities.description: A study referenced in the text that discusses the impact of general purpose technologies on productivity and workflows

entities.name: COPILOT
entities.description: Copilot is a generative AI tool used to assist with tasks, and its impact on time savings is discussed in the text

entities.name: SURVEY MEASURES
entities.description: Survey measures refer to the data collected through surveys to assess the perceived time savings from using generative AI tools like Copilot

entities.name: TELEMETRY MEASURES
entities.description: Telemetry measures refer to the data collected through automated tracking systems to assess the actual time savings from using generative AI tools like Copilot

entities.name: PRODUCTIVITY DYNAMICS
entities.description: Productivity dynamics refer to the changes and factors that influence productivity, especially in the context of generative AI and workflows

entities.name: LITERATURE
entities.description: Literature refers to the body of research and studies on generative AI and its impacts on productivity

entities.name: INDIVIDUALS
entities.description: Individuals refer to people who use generative AI in their roles and functions within an organization

entities.name: BUSINESS PROCESSES
entities.description: Business processes are the series of tasks or activities that are carried out to achieve a specific business goal, which can be enhanced by generative AI

entities.name: RESEARCH
entities.description: Research involves systematic investigation to establish facts and reach new conclusions, particularly about the impacts of generative AI on productivity

entities.name: TASK DESIGN
entities.description: Task design refers to the way tasks are structured and organized, which can be influenced by the integration of generative AI

entities.name: TIME SAVINGS
entities.description: Time savings refer to the reduction in time required to complete tasks, which can be achieved through the use of generative AI tools like Copilot

entities.name: SURVEYS
entities.description: Surveys are tools used to collect data from individuals about their experiences and perceptions, such as the time savings from using generative AI tools

entities.name: TELEMETRY
entities.description: Telemetry involves the automated collection of data to measure actual performance, such as the time savings from using generative AI tools

chunk:
collect both survey 
and telemetry measures of time saved on a specific  task. There are 
several potential explanations for these effects, deserving of study. 
People may enjoy the experience or be excited by the pursuit of the 
‘answer’ with Copilot, which can reduce or speed perceptions of 
time (Nak amura and Csikszentmihalyi 2002; Gable and Poole 
2012). Copilot may also make time appear to go faster as people 
find it easier to extract and process information (Block et al. 2018; 
Matthews and Meck 2016) , and as people gain experience with 
Copilot or use more Copilot apps they may perceive increased time 
savings due to increased ease of use.  
 
An important  limitation of the above research and much of the 
literature on AI and productivity  is the near total focus on individual 
work. The large Early Access Program Telemetry Study described 
above has some preliminary results on document collaboration, and 
the researchers are exploring extending their analysis to consider 
how Copilot affects collaboration networks more broadly, 
including  Outlook and Teams connections. However, given that 
much of the information  work people do is collaborative , it will be  Jaffe et al. 2024  
 
10 
 important to further foreground the study of AI’s impact on teams 
and organizations  going forward . Additional research is required to 
understand AI’s impact on cross-functional knowledge and 
cooperation , the social cohesion of teams , and the way information 
flows across organizations , all of which have implications for 
growth, productivity and innovation .  
5 CONCLUSION  
This report provides an overview of the findings from a set of new 
Microsoft studies that examine the impact of generative AI  on 
information work. It is our second report on the topic, and while the 
first (Cambon et al. 2023)  focused on lab studies, this one focuses 
on the application  of generative AI  in real-world workplace s. 
Across all of the studies discussed, t he results suggest that the 
positive productivity effects that have been  observed in a lab setting 
are beginning  to manifest in real -world work. These gains appear 
to vary contextually (e.g., by role or usage), and these variations 
indicate there are ways for individuals, organizations, and tool 
providers to incorporate generative AI in new ways that produce 
even larger productivity gains

are beginning  to manifest in real -world work. These gains appear 
to vary contextually (e.g., by role or usage), and these variations 
indicate there are ways for individuals, organizations, and tool 
providers to incorporate generative AI in new ways that produce 
even larger productivity gains for an even wider array of people.

Evaluation of Generative AI. EMNLP 2023.

(2024). Measuring User Experience Inclusivity in Human -AI Interaction via Five

entities.name: GENERATIVE AI
entities.description: Generative AI refers to artificial intelligence systems that can generate new content, such as text, images, or code, based on the data they have been trained on

entities.name: PRODUCTIVITY GAINS
entities.description: Productivity gains refer to the improvements in efficiency and output that can be achieved through the use of generative AI in various contexts

entities.name: INDIVIDUALS
entities.description: Individuals are people who can incorporate generative AI into their work to achieve productivity gains

entities.name: ORGANIZATIONS
entities.description: Organizations are entities that can adopt generative AI tools to enhance productivity across their operations

entities.name: TOOL PROVIDERS
entities.description: Tool providers are companies or developers that create and supply generative AI tools for various applications

4.04268 . 
Tankelevitch *, L., Kewenig *, V., Simkute, A., Scott, A. E., Sarkar, A., Sellen, A., & 
Rintel, S. (2024). The Metacognitive Demands and Opportunities of Generative 
AI. In Proceedings of the CHI Conference on Human Factors in Computing 
Systems (pp. 1-24). https://doi.org/10.1145/3613904.3642902 . 
Taraborelli, D.  (2015). The Sum of All Human Knowledge in the Age of Machines: A 
New Research Agenda for Wikimedia. ICWSM -15 Workshop on Wikipedia, a 
Social Pedia: Research Challenges and Opportunities . 
Vincent, N. (2022, December 2). The Paradox of Reuse, Language Models Edition. 
Data Leverage (blog). https://dataleverage.substack.com/p/the -paradox-of-reuse-
language-models-edition. 
Wiles, E. & Horton, J. (2024). More, but Worse: The Impact of AI Writing Assistance 
on the Supply and Quality of Job Posts.  
https://emmawiles.github.io/storage/jobot.pdf  
Yeverechyahu, D., & Mayya, R., & Oestreicher -Singer, G. (2024). The Impact of 
Large Language Models on Open -Source Innovation: Evidence from GitHub 
Copilot. Available at SSRN: https://ssrn.com/abstract=4684662 .

entities.name: GENERATIVE AI
entities.description: Generative AI refers to artificial intelligence systems that can generate content, such as text, images, or code, based on input data

entities.name: AI WRITING ASSISTANCE
entities.description: AI writing assistance refers to tools and technologies that help users write by providing suggestions, corrections, or generating text

entities.name: METACOGNITIVE DEMANDS
entities.description: Metacognitive demands refer to the cognitive processes involved in understanding and controlling one's own learning and thinking

entities.name: OPPORTUNITIES
entities.description: Opportunities refer to favorable conditions or situations that can be exploited for a particular purpose

entities.name: KNOWLEDGE
entities.description: Knowledge refers to information, understanding, and skills acquired through experience or education

entities.name: MACHINES
entities.description: Machines refer to devices or systems that perform tasks or functions, often involving mechanical or computational processes

entities.name: RESEARCH AGENDA
entities.description: A research agenda is a plan or strategy outlining the topics and questions to be investigated in a particular field of study

entities.name: WIKIPEDIA
entities.description: Wikipedia is a free, web-based, collaborative, multilingual encyclopedia project supported by the non-profit Wikimedia Foundation

entities.name: SOCIAL PEDIA
entities.description: Social Pedia refers to the study and analysis of social media platforms and their impact on society

entities.name: RESEARCH CHALLENGES
entities.description: Research challenges refer to the difficulties and obstacles encountered in the process of conducting research

entities.name: LANGUAGE MODELS
entities.description: Language models are AI systems designed to understand and generate human language

entities.name: REUSE
entities.description: Reuse refers to the practice of using existing resources or materials for new purposes

entities.name: JOB POSTS
entities.description: Job posts are announcements or advertisements for job openings, typically detailing the job requirements and application process

entities.name: SUPPLY
entities.description: Supply refers to the total amount of a product or service available to consumers

entities.name: QUALITY
entities.description: Quality refers to the standard or level of excellence of something, often measured against specific criteria

entities.name: LARGE LANGUAGE MODELS
entities.description: Large language models are advanced AI systems capable of understanding and generating human language at a high level of complexity

entities.name: OPEN-SOURCE INNOVATION
entities.description: Open-source innovation refers to the development of new ideas, products, or services through collaborative efforts in open-source communities

entities.name: EVIDENCE
entities.description: Evidence refers to information or data that supports a claim, hypothesis, or conclusion

entities.name: GITHUB
entities.description: GitHub is a web-based platform used for version control and collaborative software development
